doc.taste_notes: A strong herbal flavor, atypical for a Chech absinthe. Heavy anise flavors along with a high thujone concentration.
A very vibrant anise flavor, with little bitterness. The strongest Swiss absinthe on the market.
Light anise and fennel flavors, accompanied by an array of varrying herbal notes. Heavy milky louche.
A limited edition, commemorating Abtshof's 80th anniversary. Well balanced with a very sharp anise aroma.
An extremly bitter, yet subtley sweet absinthe meant to be consumed neat.
This absinthe has been infused with a marigold flower to give its amber color, mild sweetness, and slightly spicy flavor.
Bottled completely undiluted, this limited edition is intense. A strong anise forward, with almost no bitterness. This Blanche needs no sugar.
Very smooth and mild, with a notable anise front.
Smooth, with almost no bitterness, and a hint of calamus. Made to comemorate the beautiful era of French culture with its overall light, refreshing taste, and great louche.
Fresh, clean, and crisp without an overbearing sweet or heavy floral note.
An anise free absinthe with a dominate wormood bitterness and stimulating citrus notes. Not much of a louche, because of the lack of anise. Two sugar cubes are recommended to counter the bitterness.
A 100% organic verte absinthe distilled on a wood alambic. Very mellow with diverse herb notes and aromas.
An absinthe macerated with cannabis leaves, resulting in an unusual flavor.
For the goth in all of us, it contins the maximum legal level of Thujone. Anise is very strong with this one.
This absinthe is not for cowards
A superstrength version of the origional. Predominate anise taste, with surprisingly good balance.
Extremely powerful aromas of fennel and wormwood, which carry over to the flavor fading into a bittersweet anise finish.
Anise heavy with a dark-ashy grey louche.
Anise heavy with a touch more sweetness than the other absinthes of the same name and a baby blue louche.
Anise heavy with a milky-pink louche.
Soft anise notes up front, followed by heavy vegetal notes on the finish.
Spice forward that fades into herbal notes, and finishes with a rye-like heat.
Moderate anise forward, with little bitterness. Very complex, but with a harmonious balance.
Very strong anise and wormwood flavors, but with only a small amount of bitterness. Very intense, but also well balanced.
Extremely powerful aromas of anise and wormwood. The strong louche and smells are caused by a branch of wormwood in the bottle.
A Spanish spirit infused with mandrake extract.
A non-anise absinthe made with herbs such as Grande Wormwood, and Salvia.

An extremely rare absinthe made from a distillate of 3 year old mead, consisting of just 6 herbs to preserve the fine and sweet smack of the honey base. Overall, the taste is very fine with only a low amount of anise and fennel.
Handcrafted in southern France with rare botanicals and herbs. It enjoys a long maceration and a double distilation, leading to top notch flavor. Extremely limited, and individually numbered.
This absinthe has a substantially diverse herb taste, with notes of cognac and dark chocolate.
This absinthe is infused with rose petals to give a beguiling intense aroma, with a subtle sweetness and ruby red color.
A sweeter absinthe, with very mellow flavors.
This absinthe is full of complex flavors, rare herbs, and a spice that is both unusual and decadent.
Anise heavy, like most Spanish absinthes, but this has a light spice, and a uniquely floral edge to it with enough sweetness to not need aditional sugar.
An extremly bitter absinthe that is wormwood heavy with a large concentration of thujone. Best served with two sugar cubes to counter the extreme bitterness.
An odd anise-free absinth that uses liquorice in addition to a very high concentration of wormwood and thujone.
Starts out with a nice balance of genepi and wormwood, followed by anise and fennel. It finishes nicely with a touch of mint and citrus.
A sweeter, if somewhat earthy absinthe. It has a fruity, and bright taste, but the wormwood balances it out nicely.

This Armagnac, composed of older "eau di vie", is more complex and mellow, with richness and depth coming from its interactions with the oak in which it ages. This Napoleon has a weighted average blend of 11 years.

This is the culmination of the cellar master's blending skill. Various vintages of the oldest Armagnac are aged to perfection and blended to produce this jewel. The result is an Armagnac that will thrill every connoisseur, because of its complexity depth,
Cles des Ducs VSOP is a warm and round ear-de-vie. With aromas of fresh fruit, spices and oak wood, it possesses the complexity and richness of an aged Armagnac eau-de-vie.

Expressive aromas of stone fruit, pear and gentian root are accented by just a hint of raspberry on the nose. Elegant floral notes open up to a touch of bitter almond, cherry, and honeysuckle on the tongue with a dry spice that fades out on the finish.

An enticing nose of dried fruit, caramel, spicy vanilla and black peppercorn gives way to a lively, medium-bodied palate boasting flavors of toffee, espresso, almond, tobacco leaf and pine. Notes of raisin and spicy oak linger through the clean, assertive
This ten year is oaky but floral on the nose, with a touch of vanilla and chocolate. It imparts flavors of caramel and roasted pineapple, with a light lingering smoky tobacco-like finish.

Aged for fourteen years, the nose of this armagnac is full of spice, oak, and a hint of a cornlike sweetness. Dry spice notes, specifically clove and black pepper, dominate until an underlying tawny port-like finish begins to take over.

Matureed for nineteen years, it brings a compelling nose of raisin, plum, apricot, and sweet spice. Complex, well-integrated notes of dried fruit, coffee, hazelnut, vanilla, and oak emerge on the palate and linger through the long, mellow finish.
The taste is very nice, sweet, with some oakyness, slightly spicy. Goes down very smoothly.
Excellent balance; vanilla nose with a hint of granny smith apples; pleasing taste; nice balance of fruit and caramel; finishes with spice notes from rye.
Deep amber color; excellent nose with good floral notes; subtle oak undertones; nice mouthfeel; rich taste with caramel and oak notes; clean, pleasant finish.
Rich, complex flavors, very spicy, with plenty of mint, evergreen, dried apricots, toffee, and vanilla.
Some initial resinous sweetness, which is quickly replaced by a hot, piney bitterness. Water thins and softens a bit, but the character stays.
Enjoyably perfumed aromas and an entertaining palate, with both showing a complex array of chewy toffee, cinnamon, candied fruit, roasted nuts, dusty cocoa and tobacco.
Corn and buttery.
Finishes semisweet and honeyed, rich but vibrant, and not the least fat or clunky, and simply divinely delicious.
You’ll detect notes of subtle vanilla, raisins, maple syrup and toasted nuts on the nose. Vanilla, ripe fruit, maple syrup, toast and bitter chocolate come through in the palate.
Rye kicks off early and allows bitter and prickly, softly spiced, middle to ensure a characterful, multi-layered bourbon.
Lifted, light and delicate. Lots of rye but floats across the palate.
Medium body, touch of leather, tobacco and dried fruit.
Blackberry Whiskey… 'Nuff said. Not bad.
Spicy culmination of citrus, cinnamon, pepper and clove that sits wonderfully on the palate.
Very rich with spice well-dispersed and a sweet, caramel finish.
Tongue-wrestling vanilla, honey, caramel, pepper and caramelised sugar.
Intense, fruit, tannin, tobacco.
The entry has such a nice mouthfeel that it’s hard to believe that it’s 65.4% alcohol. Strong notes of cinnamon, clove, and oak spice come through wonderfully.

owman Brothers Small Batch Bourbon is a whiskey of very good quality. It offers a balance of sweetness and spice. I cannot say it’s very full flavored, nor is it complex, but it’s a damn fine sipper that offers some classic bourbon flavors.

The nose opens up with a familiar bourbon sweetness.  There is a fair amount of rye, along with a nice oak balance. Sweet corn bourbon taste comes out in full force.  Fair amount of oak here – a very tasty bourbon.
Delicious. Enough Said with that. Clean Glacier melt water makes for a nice, neat bourbon.
The dry grass bursts forward and is followed by a lingering bitter pepperiness.
Initially sweet with a caramel mid-palate transition and a finish of oak mixed with spicy pepper.
Unripe bananas on the nose with vanilla and Cognac, fatter textures and more developed flavors, spice and pepper on the finish

On the nose, the bourbon comes off dry and oaky, with a sharp, peppery spice. There’s a hint of sweet cherry candy, with orange-infused maple sugar, vanilla and clove. With a little water, I get some fruitier dried berry notes as well.
Perfumed start: a whiff of dried lavender, singed orange peel, dusty spice cupboards.

The nose is sweet – vanilla, corn, caramel.  The taste is a  little thin, but full of butterscotch, vanilla, caramel,charred oak and a slight, white pepper.  And the finish – absolutely delicious, sweet and so very smooth.

Most Righteous Bourbon has a nose of caramel and fudge, with initial notes of butterscotch, toffee, molasses and dried fruits. The flavors give way to slightly spicier notes of cinnamon, ginger and a touch of spice before leading to a soft, smooth finish.
Velvety notes of hazelnuts, toffee, and caramel. Solid bourbon.

Distinctive aromas off nutmeg-laden egg nog, cinnamon bark, buttery nuts, honeycomb, and sandalwood incense with a silky, dry-yet-fruity medium-to-full body and oak spice notes of cardamom, clove, licorice, cola, and graphite.
Really nice caramel-corn bourbonyness, vanilla, with wood-spice kicking in and taking over the finish.
Starts off sweet (rummy, burnt dark fruit, fig cake) then becomes dry, with dried spice, tobacco, toasted oak, and leather. Very exciting and distinctive.
Enters sweet and buttery, goes to a mild zesty citrus character and the swallow is a prevalence of “smokiness” reminiscent of a Scotch.

orghum syrup and molasses, dried figs, cherry licorice, and sour apple. Tons of punchy spices as well (clove, nutmeg, anise) in the nose. Molasses, cherry cough syrup, baked apple, and a good bit of resin and grip from the wood on the palate.
Smooth. Vanilla. Condensed milk. Coconut. Orange. Tropical fruits.
Orange Angel Delight. Caramel. Toffee. Wafers. Dry oiliness.
Starts off kinda cool and refreshing (sort of watery and sweet), but the overall flavor is sort of odd, mainly wood, with an earthiness.
Rye hits every corner of the mouth: light oils and myriad oaky, complex notes to the roof.
Light-bodied for this distillery. Firm, smooth, almost slippery. Lots of flavour development. Sweet then fragrantly smoky.
Nutty toffee, pecan pie, apricot, berried jam, and nougat, peppered with cinnamon, mint, cocoa, and tobacco. Warming, with polished leather and dried spice on the finish.

Think sawdust baking in the summer heat in an old wooden barn. While you’re at it, imagine rum raisin mixed with a bit of purple grape. They work together surprisingly well. There are hints of rye spice underneath, but it’s not at all sharp or green.
Scented with an almost waxy feel. Oak is firm but there's some finesse. Very precise.
Nicely  balanced corn sweetness with wood, a silky smooth mouthfeel.
Very sweet, honey, orange zest, walnuts and a hint of bitter almonds.
Fresh fruits, spice and oak characterise the palate, while ginger nuts and drying oak figure in the medium finish.
Bold and rich on the well-balanced palate, with spices, fruit and honey flavours.
Long and mellow in the mouth, with vanilla, oak, and a hint of menthol.
The palate is rich and powerful at barrel strength, but delightfully characterful and spicy. There is cherry licorice, caramel, and hot mustard.
Light cinnamon, sweet rye, pear and raspberry fruitiness.
Creamy, espresso, very nutty, dark fruits, the taste of an unlit cigar.
Honey, Vanilla, Subtle Cherry, Oak in the nose. The oak, and cherry sweetness come through in the palate, but overwhelmingly boozy flavor. Not as good as Stagg Senior, but it does the trick.
Fat and full with a quick explosion of lively rye and demarara sugar followed by sweet corn.
A whiskey that is somewhere between Bourbon, Rye and an unpeated Single Malt.
Sweet and fruity.  Very light, not much too it.  The sweetness increases later in the palate into the finish.
A very citrus-focused Bourbon, with lots of orange, cherry, and lemon on the nose. Candied nut character comes along in the end. Great finish.
A pronounced nose of caramel, dried fruit, vanilla, oak and spice, accented by an elegant floral note. The complex, full-bodied palate opens with rich notes of brown sugar, molasses and toffee.
Smooth and sweet corn give a soft mouthfeel on the front end of the taste. A spicey note second and I can feel it on the front to mid tongue.
Smooth on the palate and drinkable, with lively spices, caramel and corn, then a drying, herbal note that lingers through the lengthy finish.
Rich and complex, with deep notes of caramel, honey, oak and spice. EXTINCT.
100 Proof Bourbon. And Actually Damn Good. ADG.
A huge body with a well-balanced fruity/spicy palate complete with notes of pears, cinnamon, dates, raisins and sweet butter.
Spicy on the front of the tongue, restrained oak, mild rye and corn balance.
Lovely fruit, gently sweet (black raspberry jam, blueberry pie), with nougat, creamy vanilla, a sprinkling of cinnamon, and polished leather on the finish.
The sweet-corn is the first to bed down on the palate, before a strong oily liquorice takes over, flanked by a mild spice from the rye.
Notes of toasty oak and all the requisite notes of vanilla and crème anglaise, a little spice and pepper with an acetone note.
Along with the strong wood flavours present in the nose, I do very definitely taste some sweet orange on the palate.
Cinnamon, Oak, and Vanilla distinctively in the nose. The palate brings out Sweet Cinnamon, Pepper, and Vanilla.

Fresh woodsy scent, like newly sawn lumber, salt, orange, floral notes. Some peppery spice on the front; sweet and floral on the mid-palate, with a thick, syrupy mouthfeel; nice long finish, where the brandy influence really shines.

A guarded recipe yields this fine sipping bourbon, distilled from native American corn, locally sourced barley, rye, and wheat. This bourbon has a sweet oaky aroma layered with woody flavors, and finishes with hints of vanilla and caramel.
Palate is pretty rich, mouth-filling and deep, and rather bitter.
Smooth, smoky flavor with some smokiness, well-balanced.
The palette was surprisingly big for its alcohol content but it was not complex.  Pepper and spice dominated and there seemed to be a presence of red apple – quite pleasant.
Well Whiskey.
Extremely sweet and punctuated with some odd notes, including a kind of weedy herbal character that reminds me of dried spices that have been sitting on the shelf too long.

Minutely hazy light amber color. Light grainy, husky aromas are suggestive of buttery nut brittle, brown spices and chocolate oatmeal cereal with a silky, dry-yet-fruity medium body and a hint of mocha, mossy stone and pink pepper on the zesty finish.
Smooth with great viscosity and a full-bodied flavor which is dominated by potent alcohols. While there is a bit of oak in the finish, the overall spirit is distracted by its fire.
Crisp but not dry. A well balanced sweetness releasing luscious fruit flavours and spices.
Named after the city itself, this bourbon stands tall. Vanilla, spice, and oak overwhelm. Solid.
Fresh fruit, spices, eucalyptus and ginger cake.
We now have on top of the caramel, corn and vanilla a orchestral arrangement of spice. The percussion of Cinnamon chases an uncommon, but mild astringency.
The bouquet offers peppery/spicy scents that accent the dry graininess.  Palate is surprisingly sweet and corny.
Big rye content gives this whiskey a big spicy body, filled with mulling spices & charred caramel. A little hot on the end.
Taste is dominated by charred oak and malted barley with orange peel and hint of anise.
Burnt sugar, almost like whiskey liquor, very sweet, maple syrup candies.

A particularly lush, full bodied bourbon with lots of character and a balance of sweet and spice. Its age is highly unusual for bourbon but the extra oak is not overwhelming, making this a truly outstanding drink for bourbon lovers.
A soft bouquet of pine and stone fruit with fresh roasted coffee and spice cake on the palate, while the razor-sharp finish doesn't seem to quit.
It’s a bourbon.
Your tongue receives a blast of concentrated medium-sweet brown sugar and then dry and leathery old-wood flavor. There are also hints of mint and tobacco.
The palate delivers notes of dry oak, corn and pepper.
Medium bodied on the palate with a lot of cedar and corn flavor.
Sweet caramel and corn with a lot of alcohol burn and a bit of wood ash.
Middle notes of wood are what you experience most in the mouth, but not in the nose. There is still caramel, and some vanilla, moderate sweetness, and considerable spice.
Sweet, mellow sip, a rich taste of barrel-enhanced corn, just a hint of wood spice, and rolling vanilla.
Biscuit, caramel, very ripe apple, earthy, peppery spice.
Rye, oak and some sweetness to it. Vanilla and caramel come out from the oak barrels.
Hints of broccoli and asparagus mixed in with your more typical shortbread and vanilla bourbon notes.
A classic bourbon: corn sweetness, caramel, and oak are the dominant sensations with a lingering finish of charred oak.
There is a strong blend of leather and oak flavors tempered by some caramel and corn sweetness to produce a very balanced, smooth bourbon.
Subdued wheat flavour, which fortunately does increase after a few seconds in the mouth. The oak flavours are probably a little stronger here than are the grain flavours.

doc.subbrand: Pappy Van Winkle Family Reserve 20 Year
doc.taste_notes: Soft and surprisingly delicate given the age. A charred note adds to the complexity. Gentle and elegant.
Refined sweet wheat flavours with very noticeable oak-- both oak as oak and oak as its cousin flavour sweet maple.
Nice robust flavour of wheat and oak with a pleasant alcohol nibble.

doc.subbrand: Pappy Van Winkle Family Reserve 23 Year
doc.taste_notes: Sweet yields to savory with that chewy, aged Zinfandel mouthfeel. Waves of flavor wash over you, gone before you can name them.

doc.subbrand: Pappy Van Winkle Family Reserve 15 Year (Discontinued - Limited Availability)
doc.taste_notes: The opening gambit is a nice thick mouthfeel that is creamy sweet but soft. I spreads until warming cinnamony spice and oak dryness overtake the sweetness.
Soft, light leather, soft burn with a tingle from same wet oak flavor.

Very robust, with leather, tobacco, and roasted nuts. Quite spicy and resinous too. There’s toffee, maple syrup, and caramel struggling to sooth all this robustness, but the oak maintains the upper hand.

Surprisingly lacking in oak intensity, given its age. Very creamy and soothingly sweet, with notes of honeyed vanilla, crème brûlée, sultana, orange creamsicle, peach cobbler, and a subtle array of tropical fruit. Soft and mellow on the finish.
Smooth oily viscosity coats the mouth with well balanced dry sweetness with oak dovetailed in a shake of red pepper.
Mouth filling, it simply takes hold of you with wave after wave of engulfing spice oak, with the sort of tangy, puckering tannins that you'd expect from a bourbon of this age.
Lots of good wheated Bourbon notes, including some apple brandy type fruit. It's sweet with some acidity and some herbal flavors in the finish.
The Cognac is equally apparent on the front of the palate, followed by coffee, oak and then some light minty flavors.

The 2012 Parker’s Heritage Collection is a blend of Heaven Hill’s rye-based (Evan Williams mashbill) and wheat-based (Old Fitzgerald/Larceny) bourbon. Put together, the whiskey is an assembly of four grains. Quite superb.

Made after Parker Beam's diagnosis with ALS. This bourbon was released to raise money for the cause. Perfectly balanced nose with fruit and spice and some earthy undertones. A very concentrated entry on the palate of hard caramel candy nuanced with spices
A straight bourbon whisky made from maize, rye and barley. The accent is on maize, making up nearly three quarters of the mash-bill.
Immediate bitter sweet character celebrates both a raisin-fruity juiciness and a much firmer, burned-honeycombed, complex, classy and challenging, thuddingly firm with limited yield.
The Double Barreled Bourbon normally has a toffee, vanilla, caramel, dried fruit flavor to it that when adding the cocoa bean flavor makes it pop to the perfect sipping whiskey.
Very sweet and strong flavours of oak and maple are present. This is very spicy as well: black pepper, cloves, and bitter orange.
Sweet honey then summer corn, with an honest balance.
A lot of wheat and chestnut.  Nothing too complex.
Sweet notes of honey and caramel, which are followed by touches of oak and smoky spices. Long, smooth finish with notes of vanilla and butterscotch.
Cocoa, rye spices, buttery toffee, tangy, puckering rye and oak interplay. Sour fruit too.
Full flavoured, sweet, strong oak, moderate to strong spice, caramel, a little vanilla, and a little citrus.
A warming elixir with the a balance of sweet nuttiness, sugar cane, hints of cinnamon and some oak.
Delivers a burst of  intense  vanilla  and  hints of burnt orange, along with tastes licorice and anise seed, on the palate, culminating with a rich and long finish.
Notes of toffee, charred oak, marmalade, assorted candied fruit, soft leather and subtle spice.

Unique sweet oak and ripe fruit flavors on the palate, with a clean, spicy finish. While not made in Kentucky, Spring Mill is proud to legally call itself bourbon, as well as continue in the tradition of Hoosier whiskey production.

Nose of vanilla infused banana cream, flint, dried golden fruits, nutty, well integrated oak. A tang of sour corn mash. Palate brings honey and toffee on the entry, white pepper, a healthy dose of wood spices, slightly bitter burned caramel, and tea.
This whiskey is truly unique in its taste.  A variety of fruits are instantly present, followed by a heavy presence of leather and slight hint of tobacco. Very delicious.
Soft corny sweetness that is nicely thick with vanilla and caramel.
Deep and flavorful blast of sweet, toasted brown sugar, dried fruit, and some leathery notes, then drier toward the finish, with spiced almonds.
It's heavily herbal and a bit medicinal with a bit of bitterness as well.
Approachable yet playful with hints of toffee, a buttery notes, sweetness, soft mouthfeel.
Reminiscent of a fresh French pastry and German strudel but has rye characteristic are not overly sweet.
Corn, char, warmth, spice, nuts. But not much else, seems a bit tired. Opens up with a little water. Burnt-sugar caramel comes through.
Sweet from start to finish. Light mouth-feel and high berry flavors such that it comes across as almost juicy.
Full sweet flavours spread on the palate, some grain flavours well-integrated.
Slightly sweet start, with the a taste like dried papaya, interesting char and caramelized sweetness race around each other leaving a bouquet of dried fruits and warming, medium mouth feel.
Round, Delayed attack. Honey coated, luxurious. Dense and concentrated, coconut, grain, spice, seriously consistent and long.
Big, no, make that huge. Ripe, treacle, chocolate mousse, with a lift of rose petal/violet high. Thick layers of honey and nut and balanced spicy oak.
Massively intense launch, waxy honeycomb with fabulously controlled Demerara sweetness and an edge of rye.
Ripe apples and caramel with a little spice and fine tobacco, but the oak jumps out and makes it presence known here. Very smooth without any fire.
a lot of molasses cookies and mint sprigs with vanilla. A little water really makes this one sing. The palate turns very creamy.
A nice viscous sweetness that is made richer by the cascade of flavors which include the spicy rye, the oak, the char, the vanilla, all tied into a complete package by the alcohol itself.
Richly textured—almost chewy—with toffee, molasses, nougat, date, candy corn, ripe clementine and raisin, peppered with dusty grain, cocoa powder, moss.
Sweet wood notes, light-bodied but pillowy and smooth on the palate, some light citrus or apple notes.
Wild Turkey and lots of honey….

doc.subbrand: Forgiven - Blend of Rye and Bourbon
doc.taste_notes: Caramel, spice from the rye, a little bit of candied ginger on the nose. Caramel, vanilla, mint, spearmint, with charred oak on the back end of the palate.
Peanut butter, sweet and sour pork, coffee and candy.  Water mellows the weird notes, but a nice richness remains.
A splash of water reveals orange and apple related fruits in a seamless and broad aroma, and another trickle of H2O brings a black cherry skin component.
Flavors of maple and caramel, light spice, and a fairly intense blast of salted, buttered popcorn
Fragrant and fruity, with raspberries, camomile and ginger.
The palate has a combination of sweet and briny notes.  The Woodford medicinal notes are there but are brightened up by the sweetness.

Butterscotch, vanilla, and toffee notes at the front of the palate, eventually giving way to cinnamon, clove, and rum raisin. As the sip finishes, a concentrated wood tannin and bitterness begins to emerge.

Woodford Reserve bourbon aged in four types of wood – American oak as the original aging barrel to maturity, then maple, Sherry barrels, and Port barrels for finishing before blending together. The ending result, delicious.
Golden straw color. Aroma of chocolate, malt and honey. Notes of buttered bread, strawberries and vanilla that lead to long, malty finish.
Aroma of oats, rich oak and caramel. Notes of spicy cinnamon and cloves on the palate, which are balanced by hints of citrus, bananas and pears. Finish is long and warm, with a touch of sweetness.
Soft and fruity with hints of wood. Adega Velha is one of the most popular brandy's from Portugal.
A blend of young brandy and Auslese Reisling, this liquor is sweet with harmonious notes of dried fruits, nuts, and oak.

This brandy is a deep golden colour and has aromas of honey, floral notes, grapes, and toasty oak on the nose. The palate is soft, mellow and smooth. There are grape, plum and nutty flavours leading to a lingering, balanced finish.

Nice amber color with a hint of copper. Vanilla fills the nose with hints of cocoa and fine wood. At first has a rather dry taste of dried fruits but is then followed by a subtle sweetness. Peppery finish accompanied by chocolate and coffee.
This is the Pacific Northwest's delicious answer to Calvados. A true apple eau-de-vie made with apples grown near Oregon's Mt. Hood.
This is the classic Alsatian marc. In the progression from floral to
This is the classic Alsatian marc. In the progression from floral to
Quite refreshing despite the alcohol "kick." Caramel and toffee notes with a big backbone of apple. A fine Brandy.
Some caramel, apple, a little spice. Lacks the complexity of its older unblended siblings. Finish is hot.
Caramel, baked toffee/apple, vanilla, cardamom, nutmeg notes to it, lingering notes of tobacco, crystallized ginger. Medium length finish.
Caramel, baked toffee and apple, vanilla, nutmeg notes to it, lingering notes of tobacco, crystallized ginger. Medium length finish. Much smoother than it's younger brothers.

This Spanish brandy is an extremely rare gem. Aged for two years in Spanish oak, followed by four and a half years in a very old Oloroso sherry cask. The nose on this is pure, dry sherry with tons of dried fruit notes and some wood. The palate continues a

Freshly crushed apple pulp attacks the nose when inhaling this beauty. Groult actually ages the cider for 6 months prior to distillation from 100% apples (as opposed to adding pear, which is allowed). This uncomplicated, nicely spiced finish will do just
A much younger Calvados with a very bright and lively bouquet. Although dryer and less complex than others, it provides a nice entry point into the world of Calvados.

The vintage refers to the date of distillation, not the year of harvest. Very rare and very lovely, this Calvados shows notes of baked apples and apricots with a surprising freshness and liveliness for such an aged product. The palate shows vanilla and in
Deep green apple and ripe bartlet pear notes, a touch of almond, a soft mouthfeel, and a pleasingly long finish. Combines the richness and complexity of good Cognac with fresh, green apple flavors.

Lemon-tinged amber in color. Bright, brilliant, spicy ripe apple aromas. Textbook purity of fruit on the attack with a lively and lovely dance of fruit and spice flavors set in a soft texture on the follow up. Tart and lively on the finish.
The palate is quite sweet and gentle. There are notes of winter spice and dark sugars, a touch of rum.

The judicious infusion of spice bolsters notes of cinnamon, caramel, vanilla, pepper, and aged oak found in the traditional CC. This is no one-dimensional concoction, but rather the first spiced whisky that still puts the whisky aromas out front.
Sweet, peppery, and fruity, with a pleasing bitter zest. Hard, flinty, earthy rye tinged with cinnamon and ginger. Nice weight and creamy mouthfeel. Spicy Rye.
A faint maple syrup aroma arises from the glass of blended Canadian whiskey.  The flavor of maple persists on the palate with a smooth and easy drinking character. "Engineered to please"
Toffee sweet, vanilla, grassy with citric fruits, and a cleansing bitter lemon zest.  Some earthiness, sour mash, rye grain and rye spices, with a youthful spirit. Malty & Dry.
Soft, creamy corn, with prunes, spice, and citric pith. Hot pepper, and just a touch of rye spices complement a bitter citric middle.
Gentle grain notes appear, along with orange marmalade, tea spice, cinnamon, confectioners sugar and a subtle maple note.
Smooth and elegant, sweet deep and slow: cigar smoke, raspberry, soft centred yet spicy.
Sweet with a distinctive apple and maple syrup flavour. Oak is overwhelming in a grippy bite.
Sits on the tongue nicely with an almost dense chewiness. Starts softly then a gentle, subtle lift of lemon icing, sultana cake, rye and soft sweet honey.

Sweet, rich and creamy with a luscious, filling mouthfeel. The balance leans strongly towards fruit and wine with a complexity that synthesizes peaches, peach syrup, figs, sweet-sharp dried fruits, black fruits, and limes.
Maple Syrup and Canadian Whiskey….
Deliciously balanced with hints of vanilla, spice and rich dry fruit.
Aromas of banana crème brulee, mocha gelato and roasted nuts with a round, silky, dry yet fruity, medium body and a long, seamless dried fruit and grain husk accented finish.

Bright amber colour, Aromas of caramelized almond, polished wood, pickling spice, leather and chocolate covered banana bread with a dry yet fruity medium body and a smooth and balanced, tobacco and peppery spice accented finish.
Vanilla with traces of raisins and caramelized toffee. Sweet caramelized toffee, dried fruit rounded off with pleasant vanilla.
Slightly light body,slightly astringent, light sweetness backstopped by malt and oak pepper. Spicy, aromatic, grainy/malty medium-to-long smoky and sweet finish.

Rich notes of tobacco, charred oak, butterscotch and black pepper, supported by bold, spicy rye. Softer notes of maple and sweet cherry round out the palate, creating a balanced, yet complex flavor profile.
It goes down very smooth.  A good selection if you are wanting to break-in the old lady on the art of whiskey drinking.
Supple oily entry to a dryish medium-to-full body with spice nuts, cola, and peppery spice notes.
Aroma of dried fruits along with peppery spice. Initial flavors are full and robust, with notes of toffee and vanilla, along with bursts of citrus and honey. Lingering finish with notes of spicy rye.
Very sweet like a liqueur but not as unctuous or syrupy. Quite cherried with some zippy bitter citric zest, and spicy hot pepper.
The Royal Canadian whiskey… Better than Seagram's.

Very sweet and sugary, with burnt sugar and caramel that become somewhat cloying in the throat. Winey, with lots of fruit, including over-ripe dark plums, dried dark fruit, dried oranges, and a fruity bitterness.
Candied rubber? Very antiseptic and spicy. Not something to drink neat.
Vanilla and oak tastes, along with a rich, buttery sweetness that carried through into the mellow finish.

Rich, weighty, and bordering on chewy, with slightly pulling oak tannins and sweet caramels, it almost feels like pancake syrup. The medium-hot pepper does start early though and it stays long with a tingling spiciness that leans towards ginger.
Rich ultra velvety smooth sweetness on the palate and hints of sherry.

On the nose some vanilla, honey, apples, and dried apricot. The color of this cognac is light amber with glints of gold On the palate this Comandon Cognac is light and fruity; finesse and length on the palate.
Aromas of vanilla, dried fruits, spices & hints of caramel. COLOR: Dark amber with shades of copper. This VSOP has an intense oak taste but well balanced, fruits combined with a rather round finish.
In the nose: almond, chocolate, slight leather, wild flowers & mature fruits. On the palate rather fruity, balanced almond again - solid finish.

The Borderies eaux-de-vie develope a certain floral and spicy note after 12 years of ageing. Some notes of violets, orange blossoms, followed by ginger. Hints of vanilla. The taste fine almonds, some raisin. The Finish: Long and balanced.

The colour: Amber. On the nose: Early hints of hazelnut, then dried apricots and figs, also some smooth spices like white pepper and coriander. In the mouth: Some orange and ginger bread, while the aftertaste is quite smooth and long.
The cognac is complex, wooden and spicy notes, vanilla, an idea of dry fruits and truffle. Quite some wood. In the mouth: A deep and balanced mix, long and very pleasant final.

After aging in oak for 15 years, this bold, balanced cognac emerges with rich aromas of ripe fruit, candied walnut and baking spice. The palate is pleasantly fruit-forward with notes of lightly spiced apple, orange and pear, which then transform into swee

Aged in oak for 30 years, this cognac has a nice bronze hue, and rich body. The nose starts with cedar and stewed pear, leading into cinnamon and Port-like aromas. It is medium to full boddied with a suprising amount of bright fruit notes for a spirit of
Strong bouquet of fruits, some hints of honey and more fruits on the nose. The palate and the finish is dominated by woody hints - that's the cask.

It's a powerful and rather woody blend, with spicy aromas, complex but remains round. This rich cognac brings oak and leather together with slightly sweet notes of flower and fruit. A well balanced work, with a good sense of pepper and rancio. More a masc

The Paradis color is bronze-copper, on the nose: Some notes reveal some slight pepper, spicy aromas - then fruits and dry roses. On the palate: We discover a delicate rancio, full fruits - finally a bomb of different aromas, great balanced length and very

Its an intense cognac. The cognac is both balanced and complex, its bouquet (on the nose) presents some great vanilla aroma, spices - some pepper and flowery notes. On the palate: A fine texture of spicy, fruity and fine oak-influenced note.

Brillant, clear, beautiful and luminous golden amber color and look.Subtle floral nose, honeysuckle and violet. Subtly spicy with a touch of liquorice. Lively cognac perfect for long drink and cocktails.
Gold, supported by amber highlights with a citrus, almond, cinnamon, and vanilla nose. Smoked chocolate and tobacco notes with a full, round, long palate. Complex, large, and elegant.

Dark amber and mahogany in color with delicate scents of narcissus, jasmine, and honeysuckle. A touch of tawny port along with cedar, vanilla oak, tangerine, apricot, and pear notes. Velvety on the palate with an incredibly long finish.

Dark mahogany-red in color with delicate scents of narcissus, jasmine, and honeysuckle. A touch of tawny port along with cedar, vanilla oak, snadalwood, eucalyptus, orange, ginger, and passionfruit notes. Delicately spiced with saffron, and nutmeg on the
Fiery amber colour. A mellow cognac, long and pleasantly lingering on the palate. Smooth vanilla and ripe fruit flavours rounded by oaky notes.

Pale gold in color with a nose that reveals a majestic subtlety and the intermingling fragrances of sandalwood, tobacco, leather and plum. An exceptionally well balance on the palate with a long finish.

The Cordon Bleus taste is dominated by the eaux-de-vie from the Borderies region. On the nose it is floral and elegant while being round and smooth but, rather masculine, with some hints of fruit and wood. The finish is a long one.

The color is deep golden with some leather hints, and dry fruit. On the palate it is round and fruity - more the feminine XO, then it increases its complex aromas, and spicy notes come through, with wood. The Grande Champagne eaux-de-vie adds to the final
This six year cognac brings light raisin and heavy oak notes on the nose, followed by soft fig and macadamia flavors on the palate with a very silky but short lived finish.

Fresh and youthful, despite its fifteen year age, aromas of baked apple, honey and cedar dominate the nose. The flavors are smooth with hints of maple syrup, milk, caramel and toasted marshmallow that merge with sweet yet spicy hints of vanilla and oak on

Attractive golden wheat/dark straw gold color, with pears, citrus, caramel, violets, heirloom roses, and some oak and tobacco. A slightly sweet, and intoxicating to the nose and palete. Intense tastes of pear, tree fruits, vanilla, and to a lesser degree

A deep golden yellow, this mature spirit displays concentrated aromas of vanilla, maple, dried roses, and apricot. The rich, full-bodied palate introduces candied tangerine, walnut, cinnamon, and anise.

Rich amber color. Deep fruity aromas of golden raisins, pears, and apples drizzled with caramel, flower petals, and spice follow through on a rich, satiny entry to fruity-yet-dry medium-full body with layers of honeyed nuts, creamy cocoa, and spice. Finis

Fairly light caramel in color, with a nose of cedar, smoky black tea, and flowers.The taste is quite simple and spicy with flavors of leather, cedar, vanilla, and tobacco. The finish is a very long, and hanging.

Pale gold in color and very mild and quite sweet, with lots of apple and vanilla flavor on the nose and body. The finish offers wood character, some cinnamon and caramel notes. This tastes both young and refined at the same time, without a hint of that ra

The nose is sweet with honey and vanilla, floral notes and chewy oak, lots of blossom and some spice. The palate is spiced and rich, fruity notes of nectarine with dried apricot and plum, floral and oaked. The finish is on tart fruits and honey.

Deep copper in color, with a broad range of fruits, vanilla, leather, and oily nuts in the nose accompanied by sweet raisin, vanilla, pepper, and charcoal flavors. The dry finish balances out the sweet notes and is fairly lingering.

Deep amber in color, with an aroma of jasmine, candied oranges, cinnamon, and hazelnut. The taste is phenominal, with hints of vanilla, dark brioche, oranges, and other dark-mature fruits. The finish is quite long.

Noble deep amber in color with a  nose of delicate flowers, rich fruits and intense spices. On the palate, Louis XIII takes you on a world journey: to China with flavors of lychee and ginger to Cuba with cigars and cigar box and Central America with cinna
Pommeau is a French aperitif made from a combination of apple cider, and Calvados. As one would expect, baked apple is one of the main notes, followed by smoke, licorice and toffee.
Deep gold/brown color and is ripe and almost sweet (but with just enough dryness). It also has freshness, young fruit flavors and just a hint of an attractive, burnt character.

Although Malvasia (or Malmsey) is the sweetest style of Madeira that Barbeito produces, it's always incredibly delicate.  The 10 year old Malvasia is remarkably fresh with aromas and of creamy toffee and nuts followed by notes of orange citrus, hazlenut,
Golden amber in color, with an excellent nutty bouquet hinting of orange. Rich, smooth and sweet on the palate, it is perfectly balanced, with a long and lingering finish.

Light, orange-tinted amber color, magnificent perfumed nose with great class showing an array of dried fruits. Outstanding mature concentrated palate with full honeyed fruit, gorgeously mellowed, leading into an extremely long finish.
The nose is wonderful and nutty with rich creamy aromas. The palate is quite full-bodied, with an attractive freshness and a finish that leaves hints of almonds and toast.
Medium gold in color, tangy with lemon, olive, apple and ocean brine aromas and flavors. Clean and elegant, with a long, mouthwatering finish.
Medium amber hue along with a nutty, honeylike dry personality with great acid on the finish.
Dark Mahogany in color, this off-dry oloroso delivers coffee and caramel flavors, with accents of soy and iodine.
Deep amber in color with the taste of sweet raisins, dates and figs. Rich sweet ripe fruit that lingers smoothly and seductively. A powerful balance of sweetness, richness and maturity.

Thick and viscous, with an olive green rim, it is sumptuously mouth-filling with a licorice richness, packed full of sweet, sweet raisins, and impressively long on the palate. The ultimate dessert wine, serve with rich, even chocolate sweets, Christmas fa

Pineau is a French aperitif made from combining white wine with Cognac, and then it is aged in Cognac barrels. Copper in color, from a long oxidation, this pineau has a light and silky mouthfeel with notes of plum, grape, and raisin.

Full tawny. Aromas of stewed fruit, toasted nuts, butterscotch, and an exotic spicyness that I enjoyed. Medium bodied on the palate, sweet. Much more balanced than the 1965 with better cut. Nice finish.
Much more acidic than the 1963. Very bright fruit notes accompany a deceivingly light palate. Raspberry and blackberry notes dominate, giving way to some vanilla and oak ony on the finish

Clear glowing chestnut colour with a touch of green on the rim. Syrup and stewed raisins on the nose with hazlenuts and a bit of beef bouillion and some excess of spirit. Thick texture on entry, a touch of bitterness balanced by some muscvado sugar, tobac
Classic deep ruby color. This delicious dessert wine combines youthful fruitiness with a surprisingly soft complex style. An average nose, but rich with almond and old cherry notes.
Inviting nose of bitter nutskin, honey and floral scents. Excellent attack, with burnt sugar, fruit cake and assorted nut flavors.
Never too sweet. Notes of dark chocolate, figs, smoke, nutmeg, clove, ginger, walnuts and burnt sugar. A mineral driven finish.
Very dark orange brown color with ruby lights and yellow meniscus; appealing, praline, toffee nose; very tasty, praline, vaguely saline, toffee palate with good acidity; long finish
Bright amber color. Quite complex bouquet with subtle notes of herbs, marzipan, unripe lemons, wet earth, paint and just a hint of honey.
Never too sweet. Notes of dark chocolate, figs, smoke, nutmeg, clove, ginger, walnuts and burnt sugar. A mineral driven finish.

The nose has a nutty, slightly fish oil character, with a dry, wax and straw note. On the palate it is quite creamy and oily, with some definite sweetness to the fruit, and plenty of orange and gentle caramel flavour.

Intense wood aged rancio featuring dried fruits, chocolate and caramel. Elegant brandy spirit adds sweet vanillin and oak complexity.  Intense wood aged rancio featuring dried fruits, chocolate and caramel. Elegant brandy spirit adds sweet vanillin and oa

Classic rose petal and orange rind of the Muscat grape.  Full, luscious middle. Richly flavored, reminiscent of raisined fruits, nuts and spices. Sweet and soft yet unclaying finish. Incredible persistence of flavors.
Made from a citrus forward selection of botanicals including: juniper, coriander seed, angelica root, liquorice root and fresh oranges, lemons and pink grapefruit.
This grappa is made from pomace from Lemelson winery. The result is a very clean grappa with good pinot noir character, a good jolt when you taste it, and a very clean finish.
Very clean nose, with characteristics of the grape from which it is produced. Dry and robust on the palate with hints of iris.
Fruity, dry and floral on the nose with cherry pit-like bitteness and a slightly tannic finish.
Notes of peach and apricot and a touch of sage on the nose. Very aromatic on the palate, typical of the grape, with hints of rose.
A touch of blackcurrant and some wildberries on the nose. Silky smooth on the palate with hints of wildberries, blackberries and blackcurrant.
Very dry and slightly astringent nose, with savoy notes of bitter almond.
Floral and fruity nose, typical of the grape. Bright fruit dominates the palate with hints of baked apple.
The flavor was fresh and minty. The overall impression was of sweetness.
Bushmills 1608 has a toffee-like smoothness with vanilla, honey and dried fruit notes. It is warm and inviting .

Pear and grape really break away from the crowd here, with the pear having the most to say, before the honey diplomatically interrupts and allows some green peppercorn and chocolate nougat to come into the picture.
Sherry seems to be the first thing to notice on the palate, followed by fresh fruit; banana and cantaloupe. A little bitterness comes after followed by seaweed on the finish.

Smells like a Speysider, sherry sweetness, toffee sweetness, slightest hint of smoke. Palate is smooth, slight spice, nutty sweetness, medium viscocity. You can definitely taste malt. The taste is familiar, like a medium bodied single malt speyside malt.
The light palate has mild malt and spice, with slight vanilla.  This continues in the medium-long finish.
Bushmills Honey.
Very mellow Irish Whiskey with a nice, neat finish. Vanilla notes complement a moist oaky texture that leave one wanting more,
Very soft, round and complex. The flavours are hard to unpick, but there's warm honey, buttered crumpet and a hint of sweet pipe smoke.
Feckin Irish Whiskey is a smooth, honeyed Irish whiskey with loads of balance and finesse. We heartily recommend this Feckin whiskey to you.
Really nice warming whiskey and a honeyed sweetness, beautifully counterbalanced by darker spicy and herbal notes with just a touch of bitter dark chocolate.
Clean and slightly malty start. Stretches across the palate. Semi-dried peach softness, crisp cereal/oak. Balanced, honeyed and soft.
The sweet, mellow palate offers bananas and plums, along with developing cinnamon, toasted oak and dairy fudge notes. The finish is long, with sweet fruits, port, spice and a hint of barley.
Initially citric in the mouth, along with classic Irish oiliness, more profound notes of Sherry develop, along with fudge, vanilla and spice.
Silky and subtle, an essay in bittersweet balance with the final, drier, bitter notes reminding you of some decent age.
Wonderfully mellow and smooth, complex flavours of fudge & toffee spice, hints of wood & leather, gentle sherry nuttiness and vanilla.
Notes of chocolate, honey, toffee, raisin, fruitcake and spice.
Spice, citrus and then vanilla, coupled with the light oakiness of the bourbon cask.
Entry is balanced, focused, and integrated, slightly astringent and nicely fruity. Midpalate has delicate tastes of marshmallow, brown sugar, oaky vanilla, and marzipan.
Warming and peppery, the initial shock subsides, and a balanced fruitiness shows through. With water, the middle taste is longer and reveals more fruit.
Drunk neat this triple-distilled Irish spirit provides a rich though crisp taste. With the usual range of mixers the complexity and smoothness shows through.
Medium intensity nose. Malty, spicy, oily. Some vanilla, dry woody notes. Medium bodied, dominant dry/raw woody taste. Also oily, spicy, malty, dry tannins, slight toffee.
Spun sugar and icing sugar. A slight off note towards the end.
Smooth and silky with a creamy oak which seems very approachable for new whiskey drinkers. The attack is sweet and smooth with citrus vanilla notes through the mid-palate transition.
The taste is well rounded and complex with a rich maltiness. The long finish offers a hint of chocolate and a wonderfully settled smoky flavor form the peat that lingers on the palate.
Long and very perfumed with layers of flavour: lilac, oak, toffee. Finer than the others.
Very malty start followed by a very powerful grain which is fruity. Not a light whiskey at all.

The nose is oily and fresh. There are floral notes and cereal grains. Plenty of fruit. The palate is sweet and of medium-body with toffee and cereals, a rosewater note with a little butterscotch and vanilla.
Irish Whiskey with Honey notes.
Irish Whiskey with Cinnamon & Apple notes. Delish.
Honey, butter, malt, grass, with a sharp and bitter edge. This is pleasant if you like the bitter edge as part of the package.
The flavours take off in all directions. Spiciness and a pot still backbone softened by sherry. Very firm with some toffee.

In the mouth it turns into Christmas cake with candied cherries, but there is some heat on the tip of the tongue that overpowers it a little, and water does little to tame that down. Oaky but not overpoweringly so.
Young spring vegetables. Fresh baked bread, penuche and white chocolate all emerge as well.
Notes of soft raisins and Irish caramel with a peppery spice overtone. Six to eight year old malt and a high proportion of eight year old grain are used to produce the premium Irish whiskey.
Great nose, floral background notes.  Wonderfully fresh, fruity and mouthwatering

key: The Wild Geese Irish Soldiers and Heroes

doc.taste_notes: A finely balanced whiskey,smooth with an excellent body. Peppery. Spicy. Malty oak and a complex sweetness. A hint of vanilla and a lingering earthiness. The finish is long on the palate and very satisfying.
doc.brand: The Wild Geese Irish Soldiers and Heroes

key: The Wild Geese Irish Soldiers and Heroes

doc.taste_notes: Light, sweet, fruity taste; balanced and smooth. The grain comes through gently and it ends with a tingle of honey and citrus fruit. The finish is clean.
doc.brand: The Wild Geese Irish Soldiers and Heroes

doc.taste_notes: Very light feel. Slight taste of spices, but not as strong as on the nose. Some more vanilla as well. Slight hint of wood.
The aroma is quite an intense malty, fruity and toasted wood aroma. Wonderfully rich, spicy and complex. Really mellow and rounded.
Spicy, oily and fresh malty notes with more complex toasted wood and vanilla undertones.
Scones with clotted cream and strawberry jam, sultanas, dates and digestive biscuits. A hint of linseed and honey. Light and soft with hints of gentle spices.
Sweet and spicy with orange peel, sweet zesty lemon custard, apples in kilos, malty goodness, fruit, rich. Very good.

doc.subbrand: Eau de Vie of Douglas Fir

doc.taste_notes: 100% Uva Pura. Gold metal winner at Peru's national pisco festival 2011. This impressive little pisco comes from sustainably farmed grapes of the Quebranta variety. Also known as Palomino Negro, Pais or Mission, this varietal is perfectly suited for the c

A highly-aromatic and wonderfully fragrant single vineyard Muscat expression of Pisco from local Bay Area boys Campo de Encanto. Working with their contacts in Peru, they've assembled one of the most exciting lineups of pisco the world has ever known. Thi
Sweet, strong nutty vibrant taste with wood forward, not silky smooth but vibrant and out there.
Moderately sweet, and so "smooth" yet full of stuff -- chocolate, rich toffee, light varied spices, burnt caramel.
Entry is unexpectedly sweet, herbal, and oily; midpalate features long, fruity / spicy flavors of apple butter, baked pears, baked pineapple, baked apple with cinnamon, lavender, and egg cream.
Notes of pear, apple, sourdough and brown sugar dominate, but the effect is mellowed by the additional aging.
A slight banana, tobacco and black tea aroma that is very nice. With that rye punch of course. Packs a big punch with a heavy rye flavor. Heavy alcohol flavor and finish.

doc.subbrand: 77 Whiskey – Distilled from Local Rye and Corn
doc.taste_notes: Character typical to a rye whiskey is integrated with vanilla and cherry notes along with other traditional New oak flavors. Entirely made from scratch on 19th St in Brooklyn.
Spiced apple, red liquorice, plenty of spices, buttered malt loaf. Hints of toasted marshmallow.
Sweet at first then sweet and bitter. In balance with the nose. The same rosemary note.

Extremely smooth for this high-test hooch.  Sweet corn and rye.  Lovely buttery, smoky, and spicy.  A bit of raisins or prunes on the tail end. Short heat followed by very well balanced mellow aftertaste. No rocks needed.
Gentle mint, green tea, cinnamon, nutmeg, roasted nuts, glazed fruit and candied corn, all lie on a bed of vanilla and caramel.
Complex notes of mint, clove, cinnamon, licorice root, pine nuts, and dark chocolate, with a surprising dose of gin botanicals throughout.
This whisky is very spicy, with cinnamon, crisp mint and fennel. Underlying sweet notes of caramel, molasses, vanilla, macaroon, cocoa, and candied fruit.
The pre-Prohibition recipe of two parts rye whiskey to one part sweet vermouth and two dashes of bitters. We then married the mixture in the rye whiskey's American white oak barrel for 90 days.
The spices emerge more and the oak shows its grip. There is a little herbal piquant spice too. Slightly creamy.
Quite engaging for a silver whiskey, rich with apple fruit, nougat, and honey notes.

doc.subbrand: Slow & Low Rock and Rye (Pre-Mix Cocktail)
doc.taste_notes: Made by macerating six year old straight rye whiskey with lemon, grapefruit, and orange peels, rock candy, honey, and horehound.
It is fruity, floral and smooth, with a recognizable rye edge that leaves no doubt the origin of the spirit.
It's a rye whiskey. Yep. Except this ones a baby. Un-Aged.
Notes of spice, chocolate, cloves and honey.

Bottled at 92 proof, it starts with cherry and oak aromas and just a hint of those rye spices in the background. The whiskey is soft and smooth, fruity with peaches and buttery oaky notes, and as the flavors deepen the rye starts to assert itself.
Sweet maple, plenty of rye spices with contrasting moderate lemon citrus. The rye and wood flavours are enjoyable enough here.
Soft and lemony to start, with some perfumed honey. Decent hit of rye; the sourness balances nicely with the Iced Gem sweetness.
Full, rich fragrance of dried fruits, caramel and vanilla. Well-balanced mature oak. An exceptional blend of oak, toasted grains and rich toffee.

Cola, candied ginger, and dusty oak prevail. The rye is fruity and clean (minty) on the nose. Far drier than the nose suggests. Caramel and vanilla sweetness up front, then prickly rye spice asserts itself mid palate.
Peppery and floral notes abound in this distillate with a hint of sweet vanilla, causing some to compare it to aquavit.
An enticing nose of cereal, banana, citrus, honey and vanilla leads to a surprisingly light-bodied palate boasting complex notes of tangerine, coconut, caramel and spice.

An aroma of salted caramel, buttered popcorn and toffee. The aroma gives way to complex notes of sweet vanilla, milk chocolate, roasted coffee and honeyed oak, which are nicely balanced with a subtle spicy undertone.
The spice is quickly followed by a subdued dryness with a mild fruitiness, and without a great deal of complexity.
Envelopes your tongue in tons of spice and rich, crystalized dried fruit.
The beginning spice is followed by a slightly sweet middle touched with banana and oatmeal, and a long, smooth finish that was very engaging.
Decidedly mellow. Sweet on one side, spicy on the other, but not much depth.
Soft, full and chewy then builds in intensity with a powerful rye attack giving flavours of bitter chocolate, spices and a slight floury.

doc.subbrand: Pappy Van Winkle Family Reserve 13 Year Rye
doc.taste_notes: Deep, fruity, continuing with the wood and rye flavours acting as supporting elements to the brooding fruit.
Bottled at 90 proof, this stuff has a huge aroma. Citrus, smoked cedar, incense, and vanilla leap out of the glass, with enough rye spice in the background to let you know it's still whiskey.
Has an extremely smooth entry that leads to a dry, sunny sweet and sour palate with spicy notes and a very light rye.
The palate follows pretty well with corn and wood in the forefront and rye spice in the background.
Clean, rich. Cocoa. Candied orange peels. Cinnamon. Nutmeg. Very spicy. Soothing.
A distinctive sourness came on strong at first taste, followed by the chocolate depth and a rich, oaky finish. The whiskey had a notably round and rich mouthfeel.
A lighter-style rye and quite sweet, with milk caramel and bubblegum hints.
Sour spiciness, tempered by the aging that gave it a round, lush body and a crisp, woody character.
Surprisingly dry and crisp, full bodied.
Black tea, honey, baking spices and a bit of mint make this a powerful whiskey. Great overall texture and flavor.

This small-batch whisky is a marriage of two purely Canadian flavors: rye and maple. The rye emerges on the palate followed by a subtle taste of the maple on the finish. Very interesting. A good blend.
Dry, grassy, Christmas spice on the nose. Tastes of caramel, butterscotch, toffee and allspice.
Light, powerful. Floral, corn, vanilla, wood, floral, pepper, bread.
Loads of fruit, spice, smoke and a little fire at this proof. Lovely backbone of rye, spice, and malt with a little sweetness and maltiness to the fruity zest.
Slightlydry, with touches of grass and apricots. The finish is beautifully long, warm, and honeyed.
A powerful whiskey. Spicy rye against a big corn background. Some malt, too.
There is the usual rye grain magnificence of cloves, nutmeg, cinnamon/cassia, ginger and black pepper.
The New Cask Rye selection was aged in new charred oak casks, to create a darker Kentucky straight rye whiskey infused with notes of cinnamon, mint, vanilla and caramel.
The companion Aged Cask Rye was placed into a barrel previously used for rye, creating a lighter color with stronger hints of grain, citrus and spice.
Light on the tongue. Oily. Emphatically clean fruitiness. Tangerines. Very lively, fresh, flavours.
A heathery honey aroma and a full flavour with touches of Seville oranges, which linger on the tongue
Toasted orange zest compliments what is discovered on the nose and bulked out with black treacle.
Sweet and silky with well integrated sherry wood overlaying the creamy/minty character. Ripe and soft.
The sherry and oak are in good harmony. The toasty bourbon notes are harnessed well, the vanilla spices are nicely ingrained in the barley.
The sherry tries to dominate but fails. Peppery spices, lightly smoked malt, clean sherry mingling with paw-paw and a vague nuttiness.
Aromas of high toned white fruit, apple and cinnamon. The palate is soft and a touch spirity. Plenty of herbal notes abound with some latent honey, banana and a touch of grass.
An attractive nose of vanilla, cinnamon, almonds and smoky ginger. Richly fruity on the palate, with figs, spice, plain chocolate, subtle peat and a touch of leather.

Powerful oak on the nose, along with milk chocolate, almonds, peaches and some spice. Light and fruity on the palate, with coconut and malt notes. The finish is medium in length, with pepper and lingering oakiness.
The fruit fights back but it’s a savoury whisky, with a spicy chili conclusion, and utterly unforgettable and irresistible.

In the nose you will get hints of maple spice and toffee apples, notes of red berry fruits. Spicy. In the palate, Thick, creamy palate with notes of mixed conserves, lemon and ginger. Rich and malty with figs and pepper. Finishes long and smooth.
Knockdu renamed their whiskies anCnoc to avoid confusion with the nearby Knockando distillery. This 12 year old exhibits a gentle, non-sherried style of whisky.

The nose is light and well-balanced. There are notes of malted barley and honey, a touch of spice and fresh fruit salad. The palate is of medium-body with notes of calvados and barley, a touch of honey and mixed peels and notes of oak.
The nose is of medium-body with notes of soft peat smoke and a rooty character. The palate is quite well-rounded and full, there are notes of cut hay and honey, caramel and a touch of dry oak.
An immediate waft of peat smoke. Full, robustly flavoured with turf and lapsang souchong tea.
The malt is soft at first but then, the peatiness gathers pace and intensity until it positively glows.
Rich, concentrated and powerful. Sooty with light tarry/liquorice touches. The lime returns. Great presence but subtle in its own way.
First you get the sweet tones, malty kind of, some burnt sugar. Then it changes into a more spicy, peppery, and smoky tones.
Heavy but not ultra peaty, but very Smokey as in smoked tobacco leaves, leftovers of a cigar, quite chilly and peppery with a gingery zing on the tongue as well.
Burnt toffee and tar with a hint of French Vanilla on the nose. A bit waxy in taste and feel.  Grains dipped in iodine and a little bit of butterscotch.  Hot and aggressive. Not for the meek.
Straightforward, a touch spirity, more oak than character. Clean, slightly oily palate with simple, straightforward tangy citrus fruit.
The release of this 'Traditional Cask' was the first official single malt from the Ardmore distillery, this is a young whisky, but it was aged in quarter casks.

There are floral and green fruit notes here, 
traces of oak, barley, and sweet spice, all very ordered.
The mouth draws level with the nose even if the announced complexity is not completely present. Nutty and spicy notes.

A touch of cinnamon adds a spicy edge to the soft and sweet texture which captivates the palate. The classic Arran citrus notes have rounded with age and reveal new depths of character against a background of sweet oak.
Sweet, fruity, tannic, with a lot of apricot. Water does not become of it.
A great combo of dried fruit salad, peat and smoke with an earthy touch to it. Dirty sherry sort of. Sweet yet dark. With the peat giving it another dimension without going into the smoky Islay kind.
Richly honeyed and backed with a lifting zestiness which slides into spice and zingy salt. Once the dram opens out, vanilla and sultana stand out followed by notes of toasted oak.
Layered fruits and spice combine, with cinnamon baked apple wrestling with raisin and plum pudding. The dram opens out to reveal warming barley and a hint of sweet pear.

Starts malty and clean but quickly there’s a burst of fresh fruits: citrus, peaches, caramelized apples, some melon and berries. Nice hints of buttercups in the background. Hints of sweet oak with whiffs of vanilla and coconut as well.
Poached pears and honey followed by toasted almonds and a subtle touch of cranberry on the nose. Dark chocolate, cherry and turkish delights are evident as are stewed fruits and toffee in the palate.
Dried grass, custard and hints of cocoa. A little coconut, with allspice and soft smoke on the nose.  Fruity, spiced finish. Aniseed and charred oak.
The palate is spicy with the fresh fruit from the nose becoming denser and tangier. The finish is long and spicy with nutmeg and orange zest on the tail-end.
Distilled in 2004 from peated malt. This is the third batch. Dusty, sooty palate with hints of smoke and barbecue sauce. Hickory, cedar and biscuity malt. Very fruity.
A relatively limited release, the distillery is only young and doesn't have large stocks of older whisky! This 12 year old Arran offers a good sherry character. Creamy and rich.

A fruits character of peaches and nectarines rise of the surce of the whisky with a tinge of classic Arran apricot to follow. The palate is spicy with the fresh fruit from the nose becoming denser and tangier.
Aroma of ginger, honey and oak. Notes of citrus and dark fruits that are complemented by hints of cinnamon, oak and honey, and lead to a long, chewy finish.
Dried fruits. A distinct nuttiness emerges with hints of walnut and espresso. Honey, sherry, barley, touch of smoke in the mouth followed by a peppery finish.
Light, soft, oily, mashmallow-like. Good flavour development. From lemony to cedary.
To taste the palate is smooth and sweet with hints of tangerine and lime.
Very dry and nutty to start:almond and brazil nut.Some depth in the centre,then a chocolate/cacao note. Oak grips.The dry leaves blow back .
Clean. That mealy crispness comes through. Dry and slightly wooded. Attractive and balanced, quite nutty and feisty.
Very sherried with a certain soft, sweet fruitiness in the centre and dry maltiness underneath.
Definitely malty. Cloves, sweet cinnamon sticks and the slightest taste of spices
Fruity, sherried and woody on the palate as well. Coconut.  It grows drier and smokier towards the relatively short finish. It grows drier and smokier towards the relatively short finish.
Fairly sweet, toasty Bourbon notes and creamy vanilla intertwined with lush, ripe cooked fruit. Perhaps coconut. Fruity with typical Auchentoshan refinement. White peach and crème anglaise.
Flavors are quite complex, with delicate fruity, leafy, honeyed notes.
Quite big. Firm. Appetising and full of flavours. Sweetish. Distinct anis. Liqueur-ish.

Very sweet, sugary barley and more cereal notes. A very lovely malty feel, ripe fruit abound the mouth feel and into the finish, which is of medium length, quite dry, with a faint barley and a gentle mocchaccino.
Rich - sherry (cream), sweet spices. Clean. With water:
Slightly viscous, substantial in the mouth, sweet and creamy, with summer fruits and gentle spices.
Quite oaky, spicy, on tangerine, orange and menthol. The finish is quite short, relatively dry, on tangerine, orange and a lot of berries.
The mouth presents some woody bitterness mixed with beautiful fruity notes and some medicinal character. Spices are present too to achieve the whole image.
A very interesting peated malt from the small distillery, sweet.
A superb and unusual Highland whisky, Ballechin is heavily peated Edradour, and this is the 6th release in the range, aged in a bourbon cask.

A peated whisky from the Edradour distillery, this Ballechin was named for a lost distillery in the region, and was aged in red wine casks from Bordeaux. Very peaty palate with cranberries, blueberry jam, black pepper, cinnamon pastries, and nutmeg.
Fruit-driven malts with a  deep, malt-fruit roundness and a chewy, firm, medium-full body.
Kind of peachy but nondescript. Finishes with more stone fruits.
Loads of rich berry fruits. Dried cranberries, raspberries, and winter spice, particularly cinnamon, with cool wood smoke and tar.
Vanilla, citrus, chocolate, oak. Very pleasant and light.
Lots of sweet port, smoke, freshly-squeezed oranges. It gets even better at the bottom of the glass.
On the tongue it is clear that this is a very unique single malt.  It has a smooth mouthfeel and only the slightest bit of vaporous bite.
Rich and sweet, with toffee, coconut cream, Turkish delight, nougat, and honey.
Great depth with rich dark chocolate, hints of plum, marzipan and caramelised pear.
Tasted neat, there is very little smoke nor bite. You can tell there was some time spent in a rum cask, with the fruity, sugary flavor right on the end.
Sweet caramel, honey, dried fruits and some cooked/stewed fruits ,especially apples, give a lovely rich, rounded sweetness that is counteracted by the cereal and spice notes.
The taste begins with extremely smooth and sultry notes of oak and vanilla and develops into richer, spicier tones of dried fruits and cinnamon.
The nose is very rich, sherry with berries. The palate is lush and massively fruity with pears and sweet sherry notes and the finish has prunes and figs.

Honey, malt, vanilla, unripe bananas and green apples on the nose. Smooth and well-mannered. The palate majors in fresh fruits, vanilla, creamy spices and cloves. The finish is medium to long, with more honey and vanilla, plus aniseed and warming oak.
Rich. Sherried fruits and burnt sugar and a little allspice, with a soft vanilla. There’s a good balanced of peat and a soft smoke followed by a little star anise and fennel.
This whisky is tangy and very light to begin with. Here the three main descriptors are distinct cereals, grassy and fresh green fruits
Fantastic mouthfeel with a big attack of cola and salty peat. There’s still fruit present, apricots and more lemon-y-ness, but less than the nose.
There is a stupendous fruit-juiciness that moistens the much drier smoke: the peat is chunky yet manageable, the spices warming.
Esters, eucalyptol freshness, toffee, sherry. Thick mouthfeel.
Thick and chewy, with a supple depth. Refined sweetness, intense vanilla and oaky spices.
Full-bodied and mouth-coating, this expression offers an interesting balance of sweet fruits and drier spices and nuts.
Spiced fruit scones, enrobed in a fig and date syrup. Fairly light acidity, yet with lovely mouth-cleansing fruits.
Honey, Low alcohol notes, Caramel, Toffee, Straw or Heather. More syrupy malt with water.
An avalanche of bitter-sweet peat and smoke, in harmony with citrus, butterscotch, peaches and cinnamon.
Medium bodied, with a bit of initial bite. More fresh fruit notes and sweet spices with honey, cream and sweet barley notes emerging.
Very nice, spicy start. There’s some very light peat smoke, but hardly recognizable and well integrated. Toffee and apples. Some peach. Spicy finish, with clear oak influence. Vanilla.
Vanilla, Apples dipped in honey, Mars Chocolate bars, nuts and spice.
Lots of fruit, particularly luscious stone fruit. Almonds and cocoa, spice.
Sweet start. Nuts and honey. Spreads well across the palate. White chocolate, shortbread, nutmeg, Turkish delight/rose.
Citrus notes, taking the form of a Seville orange. Light peat, toffee, delicate spice.
Bit of a salty sea taste with more tropical fruit, more rum, rather sweet. The sweet goes nicely with the salty.
Cream and honey infused with papaya rosehips, eucalyptus and dark chocolate; all interwoven with rich Pedro Ximinez sherry and oak wood.
Sweet, spicy, citrussy. Oak, fresh fruit. Esters, eucalyptol freshness, toffee, sherry. Thick mouthfeel. Long finish with pine and hazelnut.
Nutty, gristy notes; almonds, hazelnuts and hints of cereal and flour. Sherried. Thick and chewy, with a supple depth. Refined sweetness, intense vanilla and oaky spices.
It’s mouth-coatingly thick and malty.  Fall fruits, plus streaks of spicy anise and cinnamon.
As the nose suggests. A picture of oak shavings piled on top of a fruit salad. Hollow midpalate.
Butterscotch sweetness, peaty smoke and leather. Very smooth and quite oily.

Fresh with subtle esters and toasted malt. Sweet vanilla flavours with hints of cream toffee, with a fresh pear note emerging. An initial burst of chilli spice, mouth warming, yet very smooth and creamy. A hint of liquorice and earthy influences linger.

Fresh with subtle esters and toasted malt. Sweet vanilla flavours with hints of cream toffee, with a fresh pear note emerging. An initial burst of chilli spice, mouth warming, yet very smooth and creamy. A hint of liquorice and earthy influences linger.
Light smoke, light peat, butter scotch, slightly phenolic, very gentle on the tongue. Not the typical Islay peat blast like Islay and Ardbeg.
Full sherry impact, but never cloying—the higher alcohol level and grain whisky cut through the sherry and add balance and drinkability.

The first whiff of the Blackadder Peat Reek has a medicinal feel to it. It gives a fiery spiciness (not unlike cayenne pepper) and then it gives a very smooth feeling with some peat in  it. Finish has cinnamon and a little cayenne too.
Mouthfilling and challenging with lime marmalade on brown bread and a dry finish.
It has a slight malty, almost bready character. There’s a hint of both honey and spice on the palate, but the maltiness and tropical fruit show through.
It had a spicy bite on the palate and feels quite 'hot' at 50% - more so than I expected.  Woody and chewy (tannins) with some liquorice
Succulent autumnal stewed fruits on the palate are balanced with a hint of the salty Islay sea air and subtle peaty smoke. The finish is long, warm and delicious.
Treacle toffee and a viscous oily yet creamy texture. Rich malt and a hint of smoke.

The peat and sherry smoke flavours become evident immediately as they ride in the currents of that chocolate accenting the flavour with herbal tones from the peat and dry fruits (like raisins and prunes) from the sherry.
Enormously sweet to begin, with an almost gristy, mealy presence. Dries out towards the middle but the peat appears light and clean.

Honey vanilla, gives way to delicate hints of iodine and salt ending with hints of smoke and sherry. Finishes with light puffs of pipe tobacco smoke, Nectar, vanilla, fairly dry with a light clean lingering sweetness.

Dry grassy nose of hay and chaff. Digestive biscuits with a malty cereal note. Meadows, with wild grass and flowers. Sugared peel and citrus fruits. Finishes with Christmas cake spice and fruit with good length.
Dry grassy nose of hay and chaff. Initially this is light and sweet, with cigars and some cedar wood moving in slowly along with malt and vanilla notes.  A great whisky that's fairly rare.
Drier than expected with a peppery kick. The waxiness is immediately there, clinging to the tongue while the smoke emerges half-way along. Great length and best with a drop of water.
A more robust whisky, with a dry banana and ginger nose and a scrumptious mouthfeel and notes of caramel, roast grain, peach and more. Gutsy and complex, and a great deal of fun.
Fainly candy like, Smoke, Peat! A much stronger Islay than younger bottlings.
Smoked peat and a subtle combination of fruit flavours which adds to a wonderful finish.
Grapefruit bitterness. A bit of smoke. Cinnamon, Banana, Green apples and butter. Pungent chilli and red peppers. Lemon tart.
On the palate it enchants with red and black cherry flavors highlighted by plum, cranberry and dates spiked with ginger and spice.
Complex and real Bruichladdich style. Seabreeze, flowery, lemon and some honey on the nose with nice sweetness, fruits and oak on the palate.
The first Organic whisky release from Bruichladdich. This is 100% organic certified by the Biodynamic Association. The motto 'Anns an t-sean doigh' is Gaelic for 'In the traditional Way'.

This is a battle between peat and spice. The smoke swirls around a battalion of pepper and cinnamon. The smoke arrives first followed by an immense creaminess on the palate, then notes of sherbet lemon emerge. Fruity finish with nutmeg and soot.
Very soft in the mouth, almost feather down lush with a silky texture and an incredibly soft flow. Slight impression of sweetness yet develops long, dry, spice-filled finish.
Well rounded mouth is silky smooth, rich and peaty and developing beautiful balance. Some smoky notes with clean sherry and lively spice. Long warm, pleasing
Peat, a little smoke, buttery and a little sweet. This whisky has a slight bite to it, nothing hot, just a slight bite.
A bit more smoke than is present on the nose, smooth and still delicate, peat and apple notes are still there and it becomes even saltier, not just the briny ocean air, but salt.
The indulgence of sweet berries and cream ensures a wonderful mélange of tastes that progress into a roasted nut and malt feast. The finish is soft and dry.
The foreground is shared between peat and notes which are both slightly bitter and slightly acid. But peat remains heavily present.  The finish is warm and long
Gentle, malty, nutty and sometimes salty with an oiliness that blends well with a fresh sweetness.
Typical Bunnahabhain peat with a nice smokey back end that finishes rather clean. A young scotch that has full flavor.

Apple and pear, dark rum spices, a little grapefruit zest and coffee beans on the nose. Spicy and sweet, notes of oak, chamomile, orange marmalade and peppermint on the palate. Very long, spicy floral finish.
Gaelic for smoky… Spiced heat opens with sweet fruits, dates, sweet smoke, cracked black pepper.
A very great mildness, despite its high degree of alcohol, a mix of ripe fruits, citrus on peated background, with very nice smoky touches.
Powerful with rich toffee and spicy notes on the palate. Very complex for such a young Islay malt.
Sweet and softly peated. Peanut fleece. Smokier towards the centre. Lovely - a gentle peat monster.
The nice balance between the smoothness of the fruit and the bitterness of peat makes room to a higher complexity, where woody touches mix with sweeter fruity and spicy hints.
Bright fruit throughout (red raspberry, strawberry-rhubarb pie, gooseberry, red currant, nectarine), honeyed malt, dark chocolate, tarry rope, seaweed soaked in olive brine, and ground pepper.
Sweet, drying peat, brine and grass. Very clean and drinkable without water, despite the high ABV. It’s a bit creamy diluted, but much sweeter.

doc.subbrand: 13 Year Distillers Edition Double Matured Moscatel Cask
doc.taste_notes: A little bit of a nutty fruit.  VERY smooth and easy to drink neat.  A buttery / silky (almost oily) swirl in the mouth.
Aniseed curiously, with plenty of oily smoke, toasty oak, malt and brine. Great balance.
Sweet at the first touch of the tongue, but soon turns to a peppery burst. It's very well balanced between the two. There is also peat, wonderfully mixed on top of it all.
Begins sweet & rich and has a wonderful oily, coating mouth feel. The peat smoke here is bright and mingles with other smokey flavors like green wood smoke and a little pipe smoke.

Typical distillery notes, from peat to salt, are definitely here. The strong-sherried character given by the first fill cask then brings sweetness: it feels like the apple rind that pipe smokers put in their tobacco to keep it wet.

Heather roots and vanilla on the nose with hints of ginger, chocolate malt and seaweed. Oily palate entry with notes of soft peat smoke and camphor, a little sage butter and rum spice with a long finish.

Sweet and fairly innocuous at first. Hint of distant seaweed, citrus, chopped green apple. Palateability is great. Sawn wood, pine cones and some needles, those Haribo sweets that have the white bit on them (you know what I mean).
Sparkling grains and sugary vanilla/peach with a suggestion of peat, harmonious balance of a wise distiller.
Smooth, sweet honey, applesauce and hazelnut. Mid-palate: creamy vanilla, ocean spray of sea salt and heather.
The velvet palate is filled with caramel and peat with warm, burnt orange notes. It finishes very dry and slightly spicy with a satisfying smoke at the back.
Complex and flavorful, with raisin and fresh apple aromas in a supersoft, silky texture. Add a splash of water to coax out intense clove, burnt orange, caramel and crème brûlée notes.
Light straw in color, this mildly aromatic Scotch is buttery on the palate. It has an acrid rubber note on the finish that overwhelms more nuanced fruit and floral tones.
Creamy with seaweed, smoke and a nutty maltiness in the nose. Clean with smoke and malt notes on the palate. Typical of Bowmore.
Malt aromas, spice & flowery dryness in the nose. Pronounced cereal grains, oatmeal & liquorice in the palate.
