With its light straw color and mild aromatics, this Scotch surprises with light smokiness on the palate, along with malty, faintly sweet cookie-dough notes interspersed with pear and caramel.
Honey, caramel & butterscotch in the nose. Flavours of leather, liquorice, toffee & cooked apples.
Tropical fruit, orange & oak in the nose. Starts sweet with cola & coconut, creme brulee & toffee.
Pink grapefruit & cotton candy bouquet.  Flavours of tangerine, black tea & a hint of eucalyptus.

The nose is fresh, clean and very aromatic. Floral notes abound the senses with a light grassiness. The palate is quite full with a pleasant subtlety to the depths. Lurking somewhere in the substratum a grilled orange lies.
Honeyed and fruity, but also slightly smoky and packing more than a decent punch at the end. The "coastal" nature opens up nicely with a drop or two of water.
Textured, sweet, mustardy, iron iodine salty. Very lively. Lots of flavour development. Light but warm smokiness.

Grilled barley, biscuit with some undergrowth hints and some farmy notes discretely hidden behind this firework of biscuit smoothness.  Some very nice fruity hints appear, developing on milk chocolate through a whole palette of very pleasant impressions.

The nose opens on sweet Turkish Delight and lightly burnt malt. Wonderfully round and creamy. Oranges, but also plums and pink grapefruit. Tonic and pepper. A light touch of nuts gives it a fine set of layers.

The nose is fresh with toasted malt notes. A hint of aromatic spices and a touch of summer fruits - raspberries. Ground pepper - warming. Creamy with sweet influences and a touch of hazelnuts in the taste.
Initially a very sweet note - Highland fudge. A creamy texture, with a hint of milk chocolate and marshmallows. Creamy and sweet. A slight hint of pepper and mint.

From that first, delectable, introduction Hedonism is all ripe fruit, fraises des bois and sponge cake. Some red pepper provides an interesting point to mull. Very sensual, disarmingly sleek and creamy. Black cherry and sweet spices, some cereal notes.
Peat, marked salinity, leans to Caol Ila in style, something medicinal. Sweet and fruity, grainy. Peat, oak. Botanicals, floral, coppery, sweet, smoky bacon, hint of papaya.
Melon, ethereal, ripe rosy apples, delicate smoke. Gristy malt, touch of black pepper, grassy, oaky, orchard fruit.

Fragrant and aromatic with notes of dried herbs, spices, oak and vanilla. Has a bourbon note to it and a peppery tang. Gingernut biscuits, toffee spices, peppery, herbal, vanilla, very rich and peppery.

Mouth warming, sweet, fresh with a subtle influence of creamy toffees.  With water there is some sweetness, with a heavy maltiness, becomes very creamy and the delicate aniseed remains in the background.
Sugary...flavor goes straight to the roof of my mouth. Have to resist urge to gulp it down. Very tasty.
Silky. Soft and embraceable but reluctant to yield its secrets. Orange blossom. Absinthe.
Floral, pepper, and vanilla, sharp.  Very long burn, then hot pepper and very dry.

Wine-like with an incredibly fruity notes of fresh pears, apples and cut flowers. Beautifully balanced. Peppery, dried herbs, honey. Rich and very fruity. Tangy, slightly sharp, strawberries, perry, pepper and rose petal jelly.
Créme caramel sweetness and toffee lead, before the light spicyness of gingerbread, rich dried fruit and a hint of cloves.
Cocoa, buttery biscuit base, hints of tropical fruit and various fresh flowers.
Chocolate and fruit, aniseed, sherry and mixed peels. Redcurrant jelly, pepper and barley wine.
Big, sweet and fruity on the palate - and quite hot. Clear and present tannins.
Medium weight with good texture and sweetness. Hay, nutmeg, sultana. Good presence.
Salty and sweet, buttery. Macadamia nuts. Butterscotch or toffee, subtle. Buttery leather notes, as odd as it sounds.
Characteristic Dalmore notes of orange blossom honey and Grand Marnier in the nose. Round and medium-bodied. Mild tongue burn, punctuated with waves of cherry, orange liqueur, and sweet sherry.
An enticing heather and chocolate nose leads to a delicious rich palate with a silky texture and plenty of spice on the finish. Worryingly easy to drink.

On the nose, a chocolate orange. Potpourri, perfumed. Fruitcake, sherry. On the palate Medium, lovely delivery. Zesty orange, Blue Curaçao, chocolate. Winter spice, stem ginger in syrup. Hints of anise and a little hickory.
On the nose, Orange, dark plums, chocolate, marzipan. On the palate, Citrus, Christmas Cake, Coffee, Cinnamon.
Fruity malt, a grassy salad with fresh ground white pepper at the tail end.
Good body, cooked fruit, malmsey. A little lemon zest, calvados with vanilla cream, desiccated fruit.

The taste is sherried (once again) along with some oak spice notes (cold unsweetened tea, old furniture cabinets – slightly dusty) but the extra maturation in the sherry casks has really worked a treat.
Smell of Oloroso and Liquorice. Sweet taste with malt and woodnotes.  Long finish with honey and a wooden sweetness.
The palate is soft and warming, a bit hot with youth and alcohol. Buttered rum and brown sugar cookies are predominant, underscored by a backbone of maltiness.
Soft, nutty, caramel. Touch of salinity. Oak. Quite abrupt, caramel.
Fresh, flowery and sweet fragrances; flavor is silky and medium bodied, with fruit and well rounded weight. A full array of sweet maltiness on the palate. An elegant subtle honey finish.

The sherry provides a good measure of lush fruit, brown sugar, and a slick texture on the palate. The sherry is clean and uncluttered, if somewhat overshadowing the traditional Deanston honeyed malt foundation.

Warm and spicy, then fruity-sweet. A dried grass/floral element also dances about. Light-bodied. Oak doesn't really play a part until near the end, where the whisky sort of grips the mouth. Finishes gently with a bit of a sour fruit flavour.
Oaky tannins, iodine, malty grains, honey, some peat as well.
Dances nimbly across the palate, offering quick pinpricks of light malt sugar, pears, Madagascar vanilla, honey and a whisper of peat smoke.
Gentle and easygoing, this medium gold blend offers enticing honey and caramel entry points, with a mild, nutty body.
Full bodied with rich, fruity and mellow notes of honey, vanilla, toffee and caramel overtones.
Dewar's Honey….
Sherry, sweet, and smoke. Finish is nice and long, coconut peeks in at the very end.
Soft and gentle taste with just a slight bite from the alcohol. On the palate there is a light fruity flavour that persists.
Very creamy, with something like sherry or brandy. The alcohol tickles the back of the tongue just before the finish begins. Ginger. Slightly like weak rum. Bananas.
Taste is creamy with a nice amount of pepper and some sweetness coming through, then a slightly bittersweet yet typical highland edge in a long finish.
Super rich, sweeter style malt, multi-layered with flavors of roasted nuts and caramel. Dessert!
Deceptively rich and full for what is really quite a light bodied blend. Fruity, with a touch of smoke. Brittle toffee and spices, along with a hint of grain, in the medium finish.

In the mouth, it is utterly full bodied. The licorice of the younger malt comes right through, but is followed by a savory banana flavor with hints of crème brulée and a strong taste of Christmas pudding.
Rich, full flavor, fruit and oak, silky,well-matured. Smooth, long, clean and medium dry.
Full-bodied and silky smooth in the mouth, smoky and fruity, with spice and a backbone of satisfying oak. Lingering smoke and citrus fruits in the finish; complex, creamy and balanced.
On the nose it is neat, the whisky has slight hints of butter, vanilla, and floral depth. There is a sense of sweetness right off the start turning into oak aging, citrus and then into a spicy bite.

The nose is fruity with toffee apples, rum and raisin ice cream, blueberry compote, sultanas and oak. Sweet and palate-coating with rum spices, madeira cake and hints of soft smoke. Oodles of melted chocolate and malt.
An inital hint of warm spice - cinammon. A defined sweetness, smooth yet complex. With a touch of nuts - hazelnuts.  With water, some subtle spice, creamy with a rounded smoothness.
Just an added bit of vanilla. Everything seems to come from the wood only. The mouth has some fructose, tannins, and some spicy notes.
Grassy peat, floural, some chocolate, sour, sweet honey, very light peat.
A complex interplay of fresh fruit, spring flowers, nutty grain, and hot white pepper all kept in place by the pith of white grapefruit. Floral & Fragrant.
Fruity on the palate with a back end of baking chocolate. The fruit notes are crisp and tart. Citrus peel.
Soft start, powering up in the centre. Sweetish, malty and hot.
Smoky with peppery notes. Charred, bonfire embers. A subtle floral element in the background with fruit flavours developing.  With water, Dry, ashy elements combined with wood/resinous flavours.
Malty candied sweetness, white grapes, a fresh apple tart, ripe pears, some vanilla, oak dryness and white pepper.
Spicy with sweet - vanilla pod hints. Fruity - apples and grapes.
Full of sherbet and fruit, creamy, fresh and spicy, although some might perceived this latter quality as being quite aggressively woody.

Smoke and spices - cloves and ginger, followed by Sherry wood. A delicate fresh fruit - green apple finish.  With water, Smoky with dry grass and gorse flavours, spicy with an oily note. Sherry notes begin to emerge.
Peppery with nutty, roasted malt flavours. Sweet Sherry character slowly comes to the fore. A touch of smoke.
Ethereal, oak, sandalwood, nutmeg, soft smoke in the background.
The palate displays notes of spice, dark stewed fruit and hints of char.
Dusty, with some chocolate and just hints of tropical fruits. Quite some mint too, growing bigger and bigger.
Clean and sweet as nose.  Citrus fruits, almonds, ginger and other spices.
Firm. Sweetness, fruity, vanilla. Gentle peat, malty.
Plush silky entry to a dry-yet-fruity medium-to-full body with elegant depth and graceful balance.
Peppery notes with floral herbal flavours. Slightly drying with wood elements present.
Initially chilli pepper, hot and mouth warming. Sweetness and nutty elements - brazil nuts.
Lots of sweet, soft malty flavours evolve in the centre of the palate, surrounded by toffee and mouth watering fruits (blackcurrants and dried apricots).
An elegant whisky with a soft mouthfeel.  A nutty vannilla comes bursting out with a soft cinnamon spice culminating in a gentle floral finish.
The attack is sweet and prickly. Gingerbread with marzipan. Sweet pretzels. Ginger and some pepper.
Mouth coating, rounded with a subtle spice. Becomes sweet and creamy.
Very mouth warming with pepper and spices.  With water, Hot and mouth warming with a subtle and constant sweetness.
Sweet and oaky. Quite tangy. Chilli and the bitter taste of pepper.
Drinks very well.  Smooth, sweet and camphor. Texture pleasantly viscous, unusually mouth-drying; soft, sweet with unusual 'spice-drawer' flavor leaving memory of apple dumpling.
Rich fruit with sweet, oaky notes, some pepperiness with floral hints.
Huge nose, lots of grain, chew finish.
Spicy with leafy/dry grass flavour. Aromatic, sweet liquorice allsorts.

A lovely, soft barley entry, joined by some slightly toasted oak but the demarara sprinkled barley keeps the balance adroitly. A full on, mouth wateringly fruity middle, subtly tropical and subtly honeyed.
Creamy and rich . Sherry goodness can definitely be found here. Lots of dried fruit.
Big, rich, nervous and wonderfully sherried.  Coffee, chocolate, prunes, dates, beef jerky, dried bananas, figs, orange liqueurs.
Deep and rich with a sweet nutty and creamy sherry, there is delicious tiramisu taking you all the way to the end which leaves you wanting more of that moorish of whiskies.
Thick, very fruity. Dark caramel, floral, dark caramel. Quite long, sherried raisins, hazelnut spread, oak.
Banana, melon and coconut, tropical flavours layered over a spicy floor. Overall, Lots of tropical fruit flavours with the toasty spice of new oak firmly stating its presence.

Big fruity notes of rhubarb, strawberry, lemon meringue pie and whipped cream. The cream becomes custard with the citrus zing of sweet wine slicing through followed by red apples and sultanas. An extraordinarily refreshing Glendronach.
Sweet with smoky notes. Some fruit flavours combined with dry grass and sandalwood.

The nose is aromatic with peppery and earthy aromas. Traces of dried fruits with smoky (bonfire embers) elements. A little toffee sweetness emerges. Tastes sweet with smoky notes. Some fruit flavours combined with dry grass and sandalwood. Finishes well.
Delightful sherried fruit, with oak, a hint of peat and delicious sweet sensations.
Full bodied rich and rounded develops slowly into fruity, smoky and spicy flavours.
Big, full-flavoured, with excellent balance, develops slowly, full of sherry sweet malty tones, and a touch peat smoke.
ots of sherry, juicy. Honey, touch of toffee, creamy. Malty, barley. Winter spice. Fruitcake, toffee, and hint of smoke on the tongue

Very complex and rich. Calves leather, cedar wood cigar boxes and cocoa kicking things off.  The chocolate richness develops in the glass, with notes of chocolate raisins, dates and figs, orange and maraschino cherry.
Subtle and complex, this scotch has an interesting combination of fruity sweetness, smoke, oakiness, and grain.
Subtle complexity of caramel, peach, tiny amount of peat almost imperceptible. Lots of flavors are playing hide and seek.
An elegant nose, faintly sweet, scented with apple and wood. It is robust and full-bodied, yet remarkably soft, rounded and long lasting.
Initially soft, then brisk and vibrant, peppery, a touch of smoke, vanilla, ginger, lime, spices and new leather.
Creamily smooth on the palate, these floral and spicy black pepper notes gently mingle with luscious fruit and a hint of sherry wood, lazily lingering to a sweet and warm, velvety finish.
Seductively woody, with substantial oakiness and lush notes of sherry.

doc.subbrand: Malt Master's Edition Double Matured in Oak/Sherry
doc.taste_notes: Malt, wood smoke, vanilla, nuts, berries, pepper, and a fair amount of sherry influence. Layered, complex, but very subdued.

The nose on the Cask of Dreams is slightly fruity and sweet with golden raisin, dried apricot, and soft vanilla. Dried apricot, golden raisins, and vanilla start the mouth off with a nice spice note that comes through as the heat kicks in.

A deep earthy aroma of sweet ripe figs and orange marmalade with bright notes of fresh gooseberries and grapes. Cinnamon and crushed black pepper rest on a base of deep earthy notes, caramalised fruits, crystallised ginger, raisins and hints of dry oak.
Lots of Sherry, honey, oak with a developing aromatic sensation. Ends with a heavenly cinnamon nip.

A multi-award winning whisky from Glengoyne, this 17 year old won a Double Gold at the 2003 and 2005 San Francisco World Spirits Competition as well as Gold medals at the International Spirits Challenge in 1999 and 2005.
Slightly herbal, big bourbon influence which has brought a wonderful "high note". White milk bottle sweets, more creamy than fruity. Barley rich, more bourbon influence. Clean and dry.
The Palate is mellow with a slightly oily and fruity presence. With water it gives up scents of caramel and malt and has a medium-long sweet/sour finish.

The nose is quite light, yet fragrant. Notes of fresh cereal and grist. The palate is very fruity with notes of Madeira and sweet stewed fruits. A hint of calvados and tannic oak lining the mouth. There is a freshness and roundness to this dram.
Fine grains with sweet honey, charred oak and understated peat; well balanced.
Firm, Slippery-smooth, cookie-like maltiness, spicy middle. Lots of flavour development.
Smooth and silky with the sweetness of soft fruits and honeyed flowers balanced by a dry oak finish of considerable length with notes of ginger and hazelnuts.
A gentle array of nuts followed by a walk through an abandoned wooden ski lodge in the spring. Some caramel as well with a couple of drops of water.

Rich, sweet and creamy. First comes a hit of sugary dried fruits (the sultanas and orange peel again) and malty grains and this is followed by a nuttiness (think of a creamy style of nut like almonds or hazelnuts).

Smoky initially with sweet, nutty flavours developing followed by a strong sherry, fruitcake flavour.  With water, peat smoke balanced with sherry and fruit flavours, earthy, moss and bracken notes. A little hint of hops.
Sweet and smoke initially. A mellow fruitiness develops - sherried and fruitcake flavours. Slightly resinous.
Fine grains with sweet honey, charred oak and understated peat; well balanced.

Exotic fruit notes of passionfruit, pineapple and apricot appear, while other interesting flavors reminiscent of saddle soap, campfire embers, aged Gouda, toffee, vintage leather, pipe tobacco and orange marmalade make various appearances.
The palate is full and punchy. There are notes of barley sugar and toasted cereals, a cardboard note with hints of vanilla fudge and notes of chewy dark peat.
Soft and velvety on the palate, with more oranges and mixed spices, plus digestive biscuits and those floral notes that are one of The Glenlivet’s hallmarks.
The palate is thick and smooth. There are notes of sherried peels and sultanas, chewy toffee and walnut, dried fruits emerge with a juicy touch.
Good balance with malty-toffee notes accented by dried oak spices. Additional notes of roasted nuts, tobacco, Earl Grey tea, sandalwood.
Sweet, smoky with a very rich mulled fruits and dark chocolate element. Drying out with Sherry oak tones.
The taste is sweet, but fresh and not cloying, with some citric acidity, drying to a medium-length finish. Some almonds, coconut and dried fruits in the aftertaste.
Caramelised bananas, orange marmalade and melted vanilla icecream. Hints of brandy, prune and dates.

This feels full bodied, viscous and velvety. The honey and caramel are initially prominent, before combining well with other rich elements such as dried fruits (imagine brandy soaked raisins and orange peel).

The palate is soft, smooth and silky with a medium body. It feels rich and sweet and has a well balanced mix of characteristics - honey, vanilla, coconut, cereal grains, new oak (think of fresh sawdust).
Silky smooth in the mouth, little spice and toffee. Original is nutty, with well-mannered spices coming through more in the medium length finish.

doc.subbrand: 12 Year - The Quinta Ruban Port Cask
doc.taste_notes: Big and rich, rounded and warming, slightly peppery, with barley sugar and milk chocolate notes. Sweet and dry flavours balance well here.
Silky smooth in the mouth, with initially quite high floral and wood polish notes that become richer and spicier, with succulent peaches.
Big flavour, with the sweet sherry immediately apparent. This whisky is quite sweet with some nice balancing dryness sneaking in within a few seconds.
The body is silky-smooth and the palate offers lots of fruit and lively spice, with dark chocolate, contrasting vanilla and a hint of leather.
Soft, silky and very complex with a distinct combination of oaky woodiness, honey and vanilla to begin with. Then the other elements come through - orange peel, peaches, apricots, and walnuts.
Silky-smooth and luscious in the mouth, with real substance and presence. Ripe Jaffa oranges, caramel, raisins and brittle toffee. Pineapple and slightly smoky coconut when water is added.
Baked stone fruits (apricots, peaches, plums) and spearmint, cherries in milk chocolate

Toffee, butterscotch, vanilla, and a curious hint of stewed fruits in the nose. Candied orange peel, sugar coated almonds, sweet vanilla and marzipan come through when tasting followed by a deliciously long finish.

Heady, fruity nose with notes of chocolate and spice. Then comes an umami-like delivery of truffles. There is a massive spice note, then something akin to chewing on pipe tobacco – sweet and savoury all at once. Black pepper comes through in a big way.
Sweet with floral and fruit flavours. Some dark chocolate and nutty notes also present.
Initially cereal flavours followed by hints of chocolate and smoke.  With water, smooth, creamy vanilla notes together with the Sherry influence.
this expression is mouth-coatingly malty, with well-integrated bright fruit notes, creamy vanilla, praline and honey. Nutty, delicately spicy finish.
The intensity of the sherry and length of oak-aging gives the whisky a flavor profile that begins to transcend traditional whisky flavors, expressing notes of port wine, pot-still rum, and rancio.

Initially hints of dry flowers, cereals and butter caramel / toffee in the nose. Starts gently on honey, fruity marmalade and apple. Quite sweet and vanillated. Some coconut. More depth when the spices kick in on the tongue. Medium finish.
Nutty with hints of smoke, lots of dark and rich fruit, with dried peels, red berries and malt.
The palate is rich and full with creamy vanilla fudge. A little toasted oak spice and cereal notes with sherried raisins.
The palate is all leafy sherry, bitter tannins and alcohol. As the alcohol passes some dark chocolate and sweet dried fruit remains.
The very first mouth is rather fresh as well, with a kind of candy acidity, and light hints of hazelnut. The overall feeling is sweetness rather than great complexity.
Sweet with sherry and floral elements. Drying with a subtle smokiness.
This dram has aroma of pears, crushed leafy bracken a hint of citrus. You can enjoy subtle smokiness and the sweet poached pears on the palate.
Full and sweet, with a grassy, floral flavour and some green maltiness. A pleasing oily body.
Once past the lips, the sweet-bitter interplay goes crescendo: coffee, vanilla, malt, Turkish delight, tobacco.
An exquisite 12 year old blended Japanese whisky. Hibiki includes malt whisky from Yamazaki and Hakushu, as well as grain whisky from Chita. The whisky is partly matured in plum liqueur barrels.
Extremely malty, and the Sherry cask is obvious. Citrus peel, maybe honey? Wonderful lingering taste.
Hot with sweet treacle, black banana, raisin, firm oak and that delicate smoke. Very sweet and honeyed.
Remarkably smooth, firm, rounded. Lightly salty. Leafy (vine leaves?), pine nuts. Lots of flavour development: nuts, honey, cinnamon, dryish ginger.
Rich, heavy on sherry and oak but not “too oaky” by any means. Honey and nice peatiness.
Sweet and tart. Honey, salted caramel, figs, mint, roasted fennel, lemon zest, almonds, cut grass, sea water and sand, pine needles, pepper, campfire smoke, gentle peat.
Rich, mulled fruits with a touch of smokiness.
Rich in toffee apples, melt-in-the-mouth malt.
Fresh and floral with hints of freshly cut grass. Elements of treacle. A delicate saltiness is also present.  Hot and spicy with some woody influences and a heavy sweetness.
Cocoa and digestive biscuits, hessian sacks, oak, nougat, cherries, stewed fruits and a hint of smoke. Rich and intense with notes of almond, nougat, icing sugar, chocolate, salty toffee and butter.
A very heavy and big bodied single malt, dominated by oak and evergreen.  It's like it was aged in a Pine barrel for 30 years.
Starts off vary peppery with a slight bitterness (dark choclate) and mouth coating. Followed by some spicy notes with hints of dates and liquorice.
Pleasantly oily. Very light-tasting at first, but with some flavour development. Honeydew melon with ginger.
Mouth warming with a subtle hint of spice, rounded young oak influences interlaced with liquorice. Mouth watering.
Its feathery and light on the palate, then the complex flavours come in with a richness like toasted nuts.
In the mouth, there is first some malty taste. Then a pleasant development on fruity notes.
An initial hint of spice. Sweet and malty.  With water, fresh and heavily malty, with herbal notes. Some freshly cut grass influences and sweet.
Sweetish, soft, malty, oily, slowly developing a slight island dryness and saltiness.

In the nose a light smoke sweetly transforming into creamy marzipan. On the palate elegant vinous note, orange zest, with refreshuing sour tangs. Finish is medium to long, with a delicious orangy coating.
Smoke, notes of barley and crème anglaise on the nose.  Sweet fruitcake with a touch of sherry on the palate. A very nutty and spicy finish.
Light, but firm. Sweet, like biting into a raspberry-jam tart. Then blackberries and passion-fruit.
Big and bold on the palate, the sweetness from the nose continues, with fruit, vanilla and well-mannered grains.
Velvety smooth, mellow taste with traces of smoke, honey and sweet spice. Foral with hints of toffee, sandalwood and chocolate. Well-balanced, long and intense.
Palate entry is warm, semisweet, caramel-like and woody. At midpalate charcoal, oloroso Sherry, dark honey, marzipan, candied walnut and even a touch of rancio are added.
Smooth with a rich, fruity sweetness. Warming with subtle flavours of sandalwood and smoke.
Rich, broad, distinctively creamy -Smooth and silky, with hints of raisin, toffee and honey.
Vibrant and full-bodied in the mouth and with a lingering malty aftertaste. Sophisticated and well-balanced.
Distinctive smoke and sweet spice flavors, with a hint of vanilla.
The rich palate offers restrained grain, lots of malt character, a pinch of pepper, peat and black jelly babies.
Very typical soft peat aromas from an Islay. Nice honey gold color that palates a sweetness first, then a soft peaty some to follow. Finishes long and clean with smoke and a soft citrus.
Great combination of delicate smoke and sweet sherry. Sherry or wine, go figure? Anyways, it's a good clash of two completely opposite tastes with hints of wood. Finishes rather peppery.

The aroma is of fresh cut barley, pepper and malt with peat perfectly balanced against this to create a fresh and lively nose. The palate is fairly sweet with barley sugar notes and with the addition of water the peat positively explodes.
Quite full-bodied and peppery, with developing fruitiness, which is emphasised by the addition of water.
Coconut. Smooth and rounded and lightly spiced at first with the wood spices and peat growing, but with a lovely fruity, creamy edge and wonderful hit of vanilla at the end.
The dryness is at first offset by the sweetness of the sherry character. As the palate develops, oily, grassy, and, in particular, salty notes emerge in a long, sustained, aggressive, attack.
Big peat hits your palate, smoke fills your mouth, the smoked kippers are here big time,fire, half burnt cinders, iodine, Lagavulin, all mixed with some sweeter sherry, and malty notes.
The taste started with silky sweet corn and vanilla, which was then melded with a wave of gentle warm peat and smoke into a lovely complex and syrupy swirl.
Lovely interplay of peat smoke and thick, juicy sherry. Sweet, hints of iodine, sultanas.
Intensely peaty. Rounded with big kick: marine character, fragrant smoke, touch of black pepper, but balanced by sufficient sweetness.

Smoke and butterscotch, dried fruit and leather: This delicious spirit is what happens when you take an amply peated whisky from the Islay region of Scotland and age it in sherry casks, which imparts a deep amber hue and a winey suppleness.
This is dried fruits and a hint of melon. The phenols reduced to fish oil, Vick's inhaler, tar. Becomes drier to the finish.
Full-bodied, rich and mouth-coating. Delicious sweet gristy malt and rich peat, woodsmoke.  The coal appears mid-palate.

Palate has big smoke for sure, though not necessarily "big" by Laphroaig standards. Initially a bit one-dimensional, it opens up and brightens with fruity background stuff like apples and pears, and a light sweetness rounding things out.
Complex. Smoked haddock, cut plug tobacco, burnt newspapers, but buttery, sweeter cooked fruit notes predominate.
Continuous gentle waves of dry peat lap upon the tastebuds but are balanced by a sweet malt middle and the most hesitant of vanillas.
Dry iodine and saltiness are countered by a pleasing sweetness that suggests toasted grains and simple syrup. The peat and smoke is there throughout.
The burst of peat that fills the mouth is quickly restrained by a sherry sweetness that slowly develops into spicy apple fruitiness.

The nose is big and rich. There is a dark peat, some dry moss and burnt heather and, somehow, toffee has softened the blow. Then, at last, the usual suspects: iodine and tar. The palate is rich and full and very chewy.

The initial flavour is quite sweet with a gentle mixture of sweet raisins and creamy apricots with just a trace of the dry peat smoke at the back, the smoother nutty flavours combine all these flavours into one smooth, syrupy whole.
Bold, yet sweet on the rounded palate, with iodine, soft peat and heather. Developing spices.
Light-bodied and medium-dry on the palate, with salt, cereal and spices, roasted nuts, a suggestion of liquorice and a delicate tang of peat.
Good body, spicy and peaty, cloves, cinnamon, toasty bread, pepper and fruit.
On the nose, Walnuts, toasted almonds, orange marmalade, ginger, cloves and malt. On the palate, Sherried peels, dates, peat smoke, lapsang souchong with honey and lemon, walnut loaf and banana skin.
Heavy sweetness, very smooth and creamy, with a delicate spicy edge. Some nutty influences - brazil nuts.
Creamy with a dark chocolate edge. Some chilli spices emerge. With hints of stewed winter fruits.

Rounded and smooth, with a pronounced hint of treacle, Christmas cake influences and a hint of almonds linger.  With water, hints of rich dark chocolate, festive fruit influences with a Christmas cake edge.
Very fresh - crisp green apples, sweet orange, with light spice (aniseed).
It is smoky, resinous, super fruity and very beautiful but perhaps globally a bit lighter than the usual style from this era
Very fresh - crisp green apples, sweet orange, with light spice (aniseed).  With water, sweet honeycomb, apples, pears.
A strong sweetness with mild spicy influences and a touch of perfume.
Quite full-bodied and very round with notes of barley sugar, toasted cereal and oily nuts with a rubbery character.
Light, dryish.  Liquorice.  Hint of cough sweets.  Fruit.
Light fruit and spice and sugar. Woody, almost smoky.  Soft finish, subtle.
Smooth and well-balanced. Some notes of beeswax and floral notes with freshly picked petals aplenty.
Medium bodied in the mouth, this Longmorn displays fudge, butter and lots of spice.
The palate is of medium-body. There are notes of citrus and dried, sugared mixed peels. There are some toasted cereal notes and orange blossom honey.
The palate is soft and delicate, with a buttery, mouth-coating roundness. Lightly sweet, oaky flavors of resin, honey, and vanilla are balanced alongside warm, malty notes of beeswax and brioche.
Big , viscous feeling to it. Sweetness and those distant embers of peat burning in the distance hit the tongue and palate.wet damp soil.
The palate is quite full with a well-balanced sweetness. There are notes of apple skins, calvados and chewy oak tannins.
Piney. Stunningly fresh peat flavours.
Not overly complex but bold and pleasing. Lots of vanilla sweetness (custard creams) cut through with lemon peel, drying smoke and spice (cinnamon and root ginger cordial).

Quite thick and full and, at first, slightly austere. There are notes of the cask, mostly in the mouthfeel, as is so often the case, but there is an exuberance of winter spice and pepper from the rich oak.

A Peaty beginning gives way to smoked cheese and oatcakes with a hint of leather. A huge syrah base marries with peat and gives a delicious tannin-like palate that envelops your mouth. Delicious dram.
The sherry leads the way followed by sweet, fruity dessert tucked within a lightly oiled and smooth bite.
Clean and dry along the sides with white oak, spice, and fruit skins - pears and apples. Coconut is everywhere, toasted, then dryness of husk.
Soft mouth feel , Sherry , chocolate nougat, Pine nutes and slight citrus.
Soft, rich and spicy with hints of oranges and peat.
Slightly slick sweet note. Youth and high alcohol combined makes it a pretty lively mouthful.
Full and rich. There are notes of apple peel and soft apple. The cereal notes offer a subdued sweetness with notes of cream and honey and a fresh blossom note.
Honey, nutty oak, cooked orchard fruits (Crème de pêche, black banana). Caramel toffee, oak, bracken, malt, dark chocolate.
Sweet with malty and heather notes. Rich fruit cake flavours with a subtle sherry influence.
Tart. Peppery. Dusty dryness. (Lemon juice?). Fresher with water.
Sweet, fruity, banana crème, orange marmalade, vanilla and a touch of oak.
Full and rich, with dried fruits and wood smoke. Long, with dried fruits, wood smoke and spice.
A nose of rich sherry, with orange, clove, nutmeg and wood smoke aromas. On the palate prepare for deliciously smooth dried fruits, sherry, orange and wood smoke.
Trainer Scotch.
Trainer Scotch.
Trainer Scotch.
Trainer Scotch.
Medium-body with a thickness. There are notes of malty barley and sherried fruits. Chewy sultanas and peels, hints of wood smoke and hops.

The nose is well-rounded and smooth. Notes of gentle peat and wafting smoke. Hints of dark nuttiness and espresso beans. A touch of honey with vanilla fudge and a little whisper of something medicinal.
Clean, peat with some sugar, followed by smoke and iodine.
Lots of caramel, toffee, and semi-rich malt, with moderate sweetness, and a dusting of garden-variety spices.
Malty start. Very spicy and peppery development, rather hot. Some peat smoke. Dry walnuts. Charred oak.
Quite full and well-balanced. Notes of toffee and Seville marmalade, shades of buttery fudge and spicy oak with peppery warmth.
Cereal flavours with spicy and treacle notes.
The palate delivers sweet fruitcake and raisin notes with hints of sherry and vanilla.
More subtle sweetness, hints of candied fruits. A rounded Sherry edge is evident and some raisin and sultana notes emerge.
Quite full with a richness. Notes of sherried peels and notes of fragrant oaks, hints stemmy dried hay, notes of dried fruits and wood resin.
Rich sherrywood, spices, treacle and a touch of smoke.
Mouth warming - mild spices. A toffee apple influence emerges with a hint of vanilla and a burst of cream soda.
Brimming with herbs and pepper, a bit of citrus peel, and spicy finish.
Sweet, malty and spiced. Some apples, rich mahogany and leather bound books. A touch of espresso.

The neat nose has complexity, including lots of vanilla, dusted caramels, syrup and candied citrus peel. The neat taste is fizzy on the tongue and quite drying, with flavours of ginger, honey and dried fruit, lime and tobacco leaf.
Floral and balanced, with notes of plum jam, cut herbs, rhubarb pie, vanilla ice cream and cold coffee. Sweet and oily, apple cider, cinnamon sticks, buttery toffee, almond, salty butter, custard.

The nose is pungent and rich. There are notes of nuts and espresso beans, berry fruits and dried peels. The palate is rich and full with notes of vanilla spice and thick nuts. A little bourbon and maramalade. The spice develops beautifully.
Light, floral nose with touches of green apple, black pepper and hints of sherry.  Well-matured on the palate, full-body big flavour with a tang of dried fruit and some grip at the finish.
A rounded spicy element develops, an influence of sweet cured meats lingers.  With water, Sweet with a smooth buttery influence, a delicate ashy edge appears on the finish.
Dried apricot, tingling. Slightly sweet with good balance in the mid-palate. Hint of menthol.
A beautiful combination of rich, nutty toffee balanced by polished oak, salt, pepper, seaweed, distant smoke and dried fruit.
The palate is very ripe and thick and thoroughly fruity. The damsons are back with juicy zeal and notes of Seville oranges and mandarins, hints of fresh cut lime wedges and mocchaccino.
Smells fruity with a soft seabreeze. Sweeter than most Oban's. Long finish with a typical Fino Montilla wood note
Sherry.   It has a sherbet like fizz to it that tingles the tongue. Candied sweetness and a definite salty hint.
Packed with oak, cinnamon and nutmeg notes initially. It feels buttery and creamy in the mouth with pleasant toffee-like sweetness complimenting the wood spices of earlier.

doc.subbrand: Aur Cymru Single Malt Madeira Finish
doc.taste_notes: The palate is spicy and fruity, with a suggestion of custard powder towards the end, which finishes with raisins and vanilla.
Coating with vanilla and oak flavours. Cereal/malty notes also present.
Sweet, but ashy, peat smoke elements quickly emerge. Some hints of kippers linger.
A rich texture and a very unique tasting palate with a big influence of leathery and smoky rum. There are nice notes of malted barley and a soft fruity character from the rye.

The nose is rich with cereal sweetness and warm barley. Apple blossom rises without effort and notes of malmsey and stewed fruits and Christmas punch emerge with spice and muffin. The palate is quite full and quite sweet.
Rich vanilla and ginger notes on the nose lead to some green fruits on the palate and tangy grapefruit notes on the finish. This is a full-bodied whisky with a rich creamy character.
Barley malt and spice, creamy and sweet. Notes of stewed fruits and peppermint in the nose. Fruity and full, with notes of malt and cherries, a little nutmeg and milk chocolate in the palate.
Medium-full, earthy and heavy, with a big emphasis on the oaky, peppery spices.  The dried orange peel and heather honey flavours are very evident.
Creamy and smooth. A hint of chocolate with a floral edge.
The flavours shift like quicksilver over the tongue. Pot pourri when breathed over your tastebuds. Light lime and floral character.
The palate is crisp and nicely mature. There is a pleasant depth of juicy apple, citrus fruit and delicate oak. Water again homogenises.
Drier than the nose suggests, but no less rich. Quite fat and fudgy, though, with a very malty middle despite the spicy fruit.
It's a little smokey, sweet and in the distance a little salt, almonds. Very balanced, easy to handle but a little medicinal at the end.
Full on, dry saltiness giving way to woody and citrusy notes.  Sweet fruits, gooseberries and green apples.
Sweet, rich, yet mellow malt. Slightly bitter peat, floral citrus and overall brighter profile.
Charring and chocolate. Truffles. Slight rum filled chocolate liquors. Water makes even more chocolate filled
Full and well-balanced. There are notes of pepper and spice, curry spices and thick honey.
Oily smooth at entry, and full of rich barley/smoke development and interplay, it finishes with a satisfyingly smoky plume.
American Oak brings subtle, honeyed hints of sweet vanilla while European Oak brings lush fruit and balancing dryness.

Smokehead offers wood smoke on the nose, along with smoked fish, black treacle and bubblegum notes. Huge on the palate, smoked haddock, Germolene and fruit gums are present, while freshly-ground black pepper develops in the finish.
Medium-bodied with a delicate, fruity character and a dry, warm, peaty finish.
Fruity and balanced. Lots of creamy vanilla, hints of spice. Oak.
Rich, coating. Herbal with malt and hop flavours some oakiness present. Delicate fruitiness.
Peat, Sea death, Brine, Seaweed, Chocolate hiding beneath it all. Water brings out lots of oak.
Full bodied. Creamy. The 100 proof burn is present and intense, but gives way to roasted peanuts, rotisseried meat, salt and light oak. Not at all sweet.
Lively and spicy. citrus and lemon, bubbly and butter. Some fudge. Light summer flowers and at the same time malt and soil.
Sweet, spicy, fruity rum merges skilfully on the palate with Springbank’s core fudge, fruit, smoke, nut and salt style.
Big, creamy palate is rounded and confident, offering fresh fruit, smoke, molasses and liquorice.
Woody. Pepper. Nutty, roasted hazelnuts. Slightly acidic.
A little bit of Springbank brine, light fruits (oranges), honey, but also with a strong sherry influence of raisins and plums.
Initially a slight bitterness on the palate with some caramac bars. Again, adding a splash of water gives a whole new perspective; lovely, sweet flavours of fresh mint, caramel and creamed butter.
Thick, sweet notes of toffee and molasses are accentuated by dark raisin, golden raisin, prune, date nut cake, and fruit gum drops.

This bottling is an ideal marriage of barley grain whisky and gently sweet oak.  But it's in the midpalate that the best work is done as the cream sherry aspect comes alive and the texture turns rich and silky.
Starts fruity (cassis, raisins) but quickly becomes spicy and sour / vinous. Orange peel, liquorice, ginger, cinnamon. More oaky dryness now. Very faint smoke as well.

Initial aromas of liquorice are followed by poached pears, chocolate, cream and marzipan. There is no mistaking the red wine tannins from the Gaja Barolo casks, complemented by earthy and woody notes.

Nose has good balance of toffee, clove and honey notes with a hint of vanilla. The taste is chewy with a good mouth feel and notes of butterscotch, toffee and honey sweetness balanced by some clove spiciness.
This whisky runs hot, but has a mildly smooth texture. In the nose comes vanilla, banana ester, and a good bit of wood. Palateability is great, bringing out citrus, vanilla, caramel and toffee notes.
Light peat and salt, slightly sweet and grassy. Some honey and pear were noted. The sweet and light notes transferred well from nose to mouth.
Definate Sherry sweetness, reminiscent of Christmas pudding, with nutty undertones.
Mouth warming and creamy with a burst of chilli spices. Some dark chocolate notes emerge with a touch of aged leather.
Fresh and lively but really simple. Broiled cereals, freshly mown lawn, hints of caramel, breadcrumb, cattle food. Taste is refreshingly nice and enjoyable.
Good, firm attack: toasted nuts, malt but with sufficient toffee sweetness to keep things interesting.
Intensely rich with soft heather and hints of chocolate and syrup.
Full maltiness, slightly syrupy, with sourness and a very big pepperiness developing.
Sea salt, pepper, pears, rhubarb and custard sweets.

Quite smooth and of good body. There is a little barley sweetness with lemons and limes and orange zest, hints of oaked pepper with a coastal edge. The peat is supple with herbal notes and cut fennel.

Sweet pears, honey, some Talisker pepper, salt, light smoke. This is smooth, smooth, smooth! The silky and delicious delivery is still very relatable to the flavours of the Talisker 10 yo, only much more refined.
Sweet, with some salt. Coats the lips, never mind the tongue. Begins with soft, sweet apple sponge in custard, then a drier crisper character emerges on the middle of the tongue.

This starts off as an elegent dram that builds on the palate to a powerful peaty, smoky, salty, peppery beast, it has complex coastal characters with notes of citrus and the most perfectly balanced finish.
Crisp peat at first then softens to enormous richness in the mouth. There's sweet, roasty malt with a heathery dryness.
Very special bitter-sweet harmony where the peat softens on the palate to a rich, sweet, juicy fruit finish.
There is a lovely mix of aromas - dark dried fruits,  caramel, nuts, malty cereals, Talisker's trademark peppery smoke, a hint of some cocoa powder.

Hints of Calvados and a touch of acidity with ground ginger. The palate is thick and rich and full-bodied. Notes of spicy, peppery oak, espresso beans and wood smoke. The finish is long and with peppery oak.

The nose is extremely sharp and well focused, with quite wonderful sultana sweetness. Thepeat, crisp at first, softens to enormous richness in the mouth, then wafts around the palate with sweet, roasted malt and a heathery dryness.
Initial brine, but not as abrupt as the 10 Year Old, quite creamy by comparison. Banana. Thick and mouth-coating with wood smoke, brine, some tin and chili heat too.
Spices initially - peppery with a toffee sweetness developing.  With water, sherry notes with spicy elements and hints of dry grass.
Malty with hints of cedar wood. Sweetness still evident.
Malt and fruit driven core, with notes of guava, honey, apple seeds, toffee and beeswax.
Soft and delicate initially, with a delicate burst of ground pepper spice, a sweetness is constant and hints of ripe summer fruits linger.
Sweet, some and very balanced - a subtle hint of spice - cinnamon develops.
Boiled candy sweetness (pear drops, the custard component of rhubarb and custard boiled sweets, hints of Kola Kubes, too), complete absence of wood for 17 years.
A lighter style of Glen Grant with a slightly-sweet grain profile and leaner mouthfeel. Classic mature Speyside whisky.
Lightly sweet on the nose, with honey, butterscotch, lime, cherry and oak. On the palate, notes of citrus fruits, apricot, tobacco leaves and sweet spice. The finish is long.
You will find the peat that Laphroaig is known for, but it has transitioned itself dramatically. The mouth is big & the finish goes on and on.
Beautiful nose filled with rich dessert notes but also a little delicate at the same time. A sharp, almost tingling entry. Crisply sweet with some citrus now along with slightly winey grapes.
A subtle nose of caramel apple, honey, lemon and grass notes. The palate has notes of spiced wood, citrus zest, caramel, black tea and cocoa. The finish is lingering and spicy.
Dripping with soft fruits and some barley-honey. Whilst a lot of this whisky is meant for blending, it still commands healthy respect from malt whisky drinkers.
Aromas of burnt wood and grain, with quite a lot of fruit as well. On the palate are flavors of light fruits, but also wood and coffee.
The peat is slightly softer yet the whisky is still an attention grabber. Overall very ardmore basic. Typical 12 Year.
The nose is of medium-body with a superb balance. There are notes of peppermint, cut herbs and cereal sugars with juicy barley. he finish is of good length with a touch of warmth.
Spice hits the palate right off. Some herbal notes build. There are some sour notes that predominate: like eating the rind of an orange.
Rich sherry fruit cake, milk chocolate, creamy toffee, light oak, a hint of white pepper creating a lovely spicy tang.
Very malty, with the toffee, fruit and more savoury elements from the nose coming through with some spices evident as well.
Sweet. Biscuity. Pistachios. Sweet lassi.
More on the body than the nose: burnt toffee, sugary, nutty. Rubbery notes.
Quite sweet and full. There are notes of barley sugar and honeycomb. Hints of chocolate orange and cocoa dusted liberally on a toasty oak.

Gentle, balanced with orchard fruits, oak, blossom, orange too, creamy vanilla, toffee. Creamy and soft with a prominence of fruit and malt. Balanced, some toffee, caramel, citrus. Long and soft finish.

Well-balanced. There are notes of chewy apple and fruit salad, hints of grist and barley malt, a touch of smoke with notes of grape and cereal. Full and punchy. Hints of orange zest and lemon juice, notes of fruit salad with gooseberries and pineapple.
Lemon, panatella and pine forest. Slightly green with vanilla in the nose. Cracked pepper and sweet barley with pineapple cube sweets. Waves of warming oak beneath.

A springy citrus blend of oranges and grapefruits which leads into a fresh, floral bloom. Smoke starts to seep through slowly, growing ever so slightly the longer it's on the tongue. Subtle sweet chillies pop up, as well as a nutty note or two.
Light-bodied and delicate, with vanilla fudge, apples and lemon on the palate.
Slightly fuller-bodied than its younger sibling, with clotted cream fudge, oranges, and a hint of peat.
Creamy malt and milk chocolate, orange soft centres, plus a hint of Sherry. It takes a modest amount of water well, and the marmalade notes from the nose follow through.
Sweet sherry with an initial pepperiness, fudge and soft fruit elements develop. A delicate smokiness.
There are notes of Dundee marmalade with fresh zesty note. There are hints of slightly sour grape and fresh hay and grass.

The nose has notes of cut fruits and the salad made thereof, notes of orange blossom and rose water, hints of crisp barley sugar and toasty cereals. Tasting notes of  cloves, cardamom, cinnamon and ground ginger, with lemon marmalade and vanilla fudge.
Subtle with a defined sweetness, some delicate spice and creamy.
Hints of caramel and a strong citrus overtone. Very slight tingle of vanilla though dulled slightly by the caramel.
Oily in the mouth, slightly earthy with brazil nuts, vanilla and lemon.
Sweet apricots on syrup and quince, sprinkled with some white pepper. And a magnificent trace of smoke.
Well-rounded and smooth. There are notes of honeycomb and beeswax, a touch of chamomile and notes of apple blossom, morello cherry, hints of dried peels and sultanas and a subtle sherry.
A diffusion of smokehouse, butterscotch, leaves and fruit wrapped into a silky wax-like flavor and velvety mouthfeel.
Dry and smooth with a good burn.  Having good spice, the scent is thin with light notes of bourbon.
The palate is soft and delicate, rich with vanilla honey and late oakiness.  A delicate, summer dram.
Malty, dry wood, vanilla, orange zest and a light touch of smoke.
On the palate, rich, sherry notes appear first. Dried plum, sultanas, freshly cracked walnuts and stewed fruit before nice wood notes.
Spicy and sweet.  Quite delicious actually.  Wish I had found you sooner!  Clean rye in a sugar coating.
Medium-sweet, with nutty notes, caramel, vanilla, and apple hints.
A bit of char opens this nose, followed by a swipe of oak, some corn, and some nuts. The taste is on the soft side with a touch of moderately rich sweetness followed by a zip of cinnamon spice.
The nose is quite pleasant with sweet corn bread, yeast, and a hint of black pepper spice. In the palate the corn note comes and goes leaving a peppery finish.

Intended to mimic the flavor of Dickel’s original whiskey from the 1870s. You’d expect that to be rough and rustic, but Cascade Hollow is actually a smooth and quite sweet whiskey, with a bold vanilla character.
Lot's of charcoal taste with alot of alcohol and hints of vanilla.
The palate has a silky texture that pairs well with the ever-emerging vanilla notes; with time the banana and smoke follow through to the palate.
A dry kick off, swiftly develops a lovely, clingy sweetness, and that ever-present liquorice.
You less taste than eat this stuff...lovely oily middle with plenty of trademark burnt liquorice.
The flavor is lightly sweet with the same charcoal-mellowed smoothness that makes the Old No. 7 such an easy-drinking whiskey.

The nose is sweet and subtly woody with a spicy undercurrent. There’s a good deal of sweet balanced with a vanilla caramel bite that I wish could be made into hard candy. Or chewing gum. Yeah, gum would be better. Long, solid finish.
Prichard’s rendition is overwhelmingly, well, sweet, a syrupy concoction that is overwhelmingly sugary, but which offers vague Bourbon character in the finish.
Very much a Bourbon at heart, sweet caramel notes balanced by a body that hints at its corn-based roots, a little black pepper, and vanilla on the finish.
Alibi’s flavor profile harkens back to America’s past when whiskey was served in a shot glass or flask. Alibi is a corn-based whiskey that contains elements of rye and malted barley.

The entry is incredibly smooth considering that it’s cask strength. The first note is caramel which opens up to more cinnamon, cornbread, dark chocolate and brown sugar. The heat really comes in at the mid palate and sticks around through the finish.
The entry is a symphony of corn flavors with roasted corn, warm corn bread, and blue corn tortillas.
Up-front flavors of grilled sweet corn and chewing tobacco from the palate.  Just beneath these savory components are hints of cherry and maybe even some huckleberry.
Aromas of sweet fruit, baking spices, jasmine, flowers and herbs are repeated on the palate which also features notes of oak, rye, citrus and slight hints of sweet tea and rosemary.
There are notes of freshly baked sweet buns, a stewed fruit note and a mixed nut character.

doc.subbrand: 77 Whiskey – Distilled from New York Wheat
doc.taste_notes: Soft sweet scents of vanilla, maple & citrus emerge from the glass. Smooth, round, sweet and easy drinking with flavors of maple & cinnamon make it easy to understand why the distiller refers to it as "French Toast Breakfast".
Butterscotch, nut brittle, and hazelnut nutella really wooing the sweet-tooth.
Sharp and dry, with oak dominant.
Otay Buckwheat Spirit has a rich and spicy nose, and opens up to notes of raisins, vanilla, orange peel and a touch of chocolate.
Slightly sweet, gently fruity, with that bitter orange flavour starting to come thru before the peat and iodine rise up.
Sweetish corn and a trace of rye, leather and mint notes, slight citrus and on more warming: char, toffee, some spiciness, and a faint trace of orange/maple.
The nose is layered, with the rich island peat filling the middle, bacony beechwood curling out from underneath, and more delicate cherry top notes. The palate exemplifies the nose quite nicely.
Smooth, sticky mouthfeel compliments the fruity malt sweetness (strawberry/pear/banana becoming vanilla) in perfect balance with the acidity and black-pepper bitterness.
On the nose, the TX Blended is like pecan pie. It’s very sweet, with heavy notes of vanilla, toasted nuts, and caramel. On the tongue, it’s simply mild. There’s no rye spice, big burn, or loud notes.
Soft, satiny entry to a light-to-medium body with hints of anise, pear and apple.
Vanilla, honey, toffee with some nice fruit, blueberries and black cherries. Chai spices - nutmeg, cinnamon and orange zest. Salty caramels. Tobacco. Gentle smoke!
Fried corn, more corn bread, and a considerable mentholic quality stand out; some tropical fruits (pineapples?) also come into play.
Oak and Apple wood are very prevalent in this whiskey giving it a very sweet taste.
With a surprising banana nose, this white whiskey continues to amaze with hints of dried fruits and a touch of cantaloupe.
With red currant undertones and a hint of tapioca, this multifaceted spirit rounds off with a ripe pear and fig finish.
Its delicate apricot blossom aroma turns creamy on the palate, followed by a butterscotch and almond finish.
Natural faint sweetness,Candied Nuts & Fruit,Hint of Brown Sugar.
100% Wheat - notes of banana and caramel with a rich, buttery finish
Wonderful flavour of white corn straight off the cob.  Bold yet surprisingly mellow.
Soft, silky fruity-yet-dry medium-to-full body and a lively raisin scone, mossy earth, wet stone, and peppery spice finish.
It has a honey-leathery aroma and flavor, with a slight amount of saltiness in the finish.
Nothing special.  Virginia moonshine.
The sourness becomes a secondary characteristic to an appealingly sweet frosting/birthday-cake sort of sensation.
Medium bodied, slightly sweet (but not viscous) entry, pronounced - but pleasant - alcohol, with a great touch of spice.
